\end{exercise}

\subsection{Coverings of pro-$C^*$-algebras}

\paragraph*{}
Suppose that
\be\nonumber
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, x_0\right) }\bydef\\
\bydef \left\{\left\{p_\la:\left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \sX, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}, \left\{p^\mu_{ \nu}:\left( \sX_\mu, x^\mu_0\right) \to \left( \sX_\nu, x^\nu_0\right)\right\}_{\substack{\mu,\nu\in\La\\
		\mu\ge\nu}} \right\}\\
%\in \\
\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \sX, x_0\right) }\in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\text{pt}}.
\end{split}
\ee	
is  a pointed topological finite covering category (cf. Definition \ref{top_sec_p_defn}). Assume that  $p_\la$ and $p^\mu_\nu$ are finite-fold transitive $\bt$-coverings for all $\la, \mu, \nu \in \La$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_bt_cov_defn}).  If $F$ 
is  distinguished family of compact subsets $F$ (cf. Definition \ref{comm_pro_dist_defn}) on $\sX$ and for any $\la\in \La$ 
and for any $\la$ there is the $p$-{lift} of $F$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_pro_inv_defn}). Moreover there are injective *-homomorphisms 
\bean
C_F\left( p_\la\right): C_F\left(\sX\right)\hookto C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right),\\
C_{ p_\nu^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}\left( p^\mu_\nu\right): C_{p_\nu^{-1}\left(F \right)_c }\left(\sX_\nu\right)\hookto C_{p_\mu^{-1}\left(F \right)_c }\left(\sX_\mu\right)
\eean
From the Theorem \ref{top_pro_fin_thm} it follows that these *-homomorphisms are {noncommutative finite-fold  coverings  of pro-$C^*$ algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{pro_fin_defn}). So the pair 
\be\label{top_pro_cat_eqn}
\mathfrak{S}_{C_F\left(\sX \right) }\bydef \left\{ \left\{C_F\left( p_\la\right)\right\}_{\la\in \La}, \left\{C_{p_\nu^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}\left( p^\mu_\nu\right)\right\}_{\mu,\nu\in\La}\right\}
\ee
is a {pointed algebraical  finite covering category of pro-$C^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_pt_pro_defn}).
\begin{empt}\label{top_pro_empt}
Let us obtain the $\mathfrak{S}_{C^*\left(\sX, F \right) }$-specialization of the given by \ref{inv_pro_lim_empt} construction. If  $b\left( \mathfrak{S}_{C^*\left(\sX, F \right) }\right)$ is given by \eqref{bounded_cat_eqn} then it corresponds to the following injective *-homomorphisms 
\bean
C\left(\bt p\right): C\left(\bt\sX\right)\hookto C\left(\bt\sX_\la\right),\\
C\left(\bt p^\mu_\nu\right): C\left(\bt\sX_\nu\right)\hookto C\left(\bt\sX_\mu\right)
\eean
which define  is pointed algebraical  finite covering category 
\be\label{top_csbt_eqn}
\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\bt\sX \right) }\bydef \left\{ \left\{C\left(\bt p_\la\right)\right\}_{\la\in \La}, \left\{C^*\left(\bt p^\mu_\nu\right)\right\}_{\mu,\nu\in\La}\right\}
\ee
Above *-homomorphisms correspond to a pointed topological finite covering category (cf. Definition \ref{top_sec_p_defn})
\be\label{top_sbt_eqn}
\mathfrak{S}_{\bt\sX}\bydef \left\{ \left\{\bt p_\la: \bt\sX_{\la}\to \bt\sX\right\}_{\la\in \La}, \left\{\bt p^\mu_\nu: \bt\sX_{\mu}\to \bt\sX_\nu\right\}_{\mu,\nu\in\La}\right\}
\ee
If $\overline\sY$ is the topological disconnected inverse limit  of $\mathfrak{S}_{\bt\sX}$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}) then from the Theorem \ref{comm_main_thm} it follows that $\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\bt\sX \right) }$ is good (cf. Definition \ref{mains_defn})
and the triple 
\bean
\left(C\left(\bt\sX \right), C_0\left( \overline\sY\right), G\left(\left.\overline\sY\right|\bt\sX\right)  \right) 
\eean
is the disconnected inverse noncommutative limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\bt\sX \right) }$ (cf.  Definition \ref{main_defn}). The $C^*$-algebra $C_0\left( \overline\sY\right)$ corresponds to $\overline B$ in the construction \ref{inv_pro_lim_empt}. If $C^*\left(G, R \right)$ is the specialization of described in  \ref{inv_pro_lim_empt} pro-$C^*$-algebra then $b\left( C^*\left(G, R \right)\right)= M\left( C_0\left( \overline\sY\right)\right) = C_b\left( \overline\sY\right)$. If $\bt\overline p: \overline\sY\to \bt\sX$ is the natural covering and $\overline\sX \bydef \bt\overline p^{-1}\left( \sX\right)$ then $\overline p\bydef\left.\overline p\right|_{\overline\sX}:\overline\sX \to \sX$ is a covering and for all $\la\in\La$ there is the natural covering  $\overline p_\la: \overline\sX\to \sX_\la$.  According to the proof of the Proposition \ref{pro_dir_lim_prop} any seminorm on $\varinjlim C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right)$ corresponds to a family $\left\{p_{K_\la}\right\}_{\la\in\La}\in\prod_{\la \in \La}S\left(C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right) \right)$ where $K_\la\in p_\la^{-1}\left(F \right)_c$.The family should satisfy  to the equation \eqref{seminorms_inv_lim}, i.e.
\be\label{top_pmnp_eqn}
p_{K_\mu}\circ C_0\left(p^\mu_\nu \right) \le p_{K_\nu},
\ee
or equivalently $p^\mu_\nu\left( K_\mu\right)\subset K_\nu$. The set 
\be\label{top_ok_eqn}
\overline K = \bigcap_{\la\in\La}\overline p^{-1}_\la\left( {K_\la}\right) \subset \overline\sX
\ee
is a closed and $\overline p \left(\overline K \right) \in F$.  Denote by
\be\label{top_okd_eqn}
\overline p^{-1}\left( F\right) \bydef \left\{\left.\overline K \subset \overline\sX\right| \overline K \text{ is closed AND }\overline p\left(\overline K \right)\in F \right\}
\ee

The given by the family $\left\{p_{K_\la}\right\}_{\la\in\La}$ seminorm is equivalent to the seminorm given by the family  $\left\{\overline p_\la\left( \overline K\right) \right\}_{\la\in\La}$. If $\widehat K\bydef \varprojlim \overline p_\la\left( \overline K\right)$ then 
$$
\left( \varinjlim C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right)\right)_{\left\{\overline p_\la\left( \overline K\right) \right\}}\cong C\left(\widehat K \right) 
$$
Otherwise there is the natural bijective continuous map $\overline K\to \widehat K$ which induces an injective *-homomorphism $\iota_{\widehat K }:C\left(\widehat K \right)\hookto C_b\left( \overline K\right)$. The associated with the family $\left\{\overline p_\la\left( \overline K\right) \right\}$ seminorm is given by
$$
a \mapsto \left\| \iota_{\widehat K }\left( a\right) \right\| 
$$
If $\left(G, R\right)$ is a specialization of the given by \ref{inv_pro_lim_empt} weakly admissible set then any representation of $\left(G, R\right)$ correspond to the given by \eqref{top_ok_eqn} set 
$\overline K$. If $p_{\overline K}$ is the seminorm which corresponds to $\overline K$ then for any $a\in G$ one has
$$
p_{\overline K}\left(a \right)= \begin{cases}
\sup_{x \in \overline K}a\left(x\right)& a \in C_b\left(\overline \sY \right) \\
 p_{\overline K}\left(\iota_{\widehat K }\left( a\right) \right)& a \in \varinjlim C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right)
\end{cases} 
$$
$C^*\left(G, R\right)$ is the Hausdorff completion of free algebra $F\left( G\right)$ with respect to seminorms  $p_{\overline K}$ (cf. Remark \ref{uni_pro_c_rep_rem}).
 It follows that 
\be\label{top_cgr_eqn}
C^*\left(G, R\right)=\varprojlim_{\overline K \in \overline p^{-1}\left(F \right) } C_b\left(\overline \sY \right)_{p_{\overline K}}
\ee
Consider the family $\left\{p_{K_\la}\right\}_{\la\in\La}$ once again. If $K \bydef K_{\la_{\text{min}}}$ then from \eqref{top_pmnp_eqn} it follows that $K_\la \subset p^{-1}_\la\left(K \right)$ so one has $p_{K_\la} \le p_{p^{-1}_\la\left(K \right)}$ it turns out that there is there is a surjecuve *-homomorphism
		$$
		\left( \varinjlim C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right)\right)_{\left\{\overline p^{-1}_\la\left( K\right) \right\}}\to 	\left( \varinjlim C_{p_\la^{-1}\left(F\right)_c}\left(\sX_\la\right)\right)_{\left\{\overline p_\la\left( \overline K\right) \right\}}	
		$$
It follows that
\be\label{top_pk_eqn}
C^*\left(G, R\right)=\varprojlim_{K \in F} C_b\left(\overline \sY \right)_{p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) }}
\ee
Suppose than $\sX$ is locally connected and for any $x \in \sX$ we select an open connected neighborhood $\sV_x$ evenly covered by $\overline p$ (cf. Definition \ref{comm_cov_pr_defn}). Also select an compact neighborhood $K_x$ of $x$ such that $K_x\subset  \sV_x$ and denote by $\sU_x \subset K_x$ the maximal open subset of $K_x$. One has
\be\label{top_xin_eqn}
x \in  \sU_x \subset K_x \subset \sV_x
\ee
Denote by $F'$ the set of the constructed above compact sets and let
\be
F_{\overline p}\bydef \left\{\left.K \subset \sX\right| \exists K'\in F' \quad \exists K]'\in F'\quad K = K'\cap K'' \right\}\subset F.
\ee
Consider $F_{\overline p}$ as an indexed set, so  the equation \ref{top_xin_eqn} can be rewritten as
\be\label{top_xina_eqn}
\sU_\a \subset K_\a \subset \sV_\a\quad \a \in F_{\overline p}
\ee
For any $K \in F$ there is a finite set $\left\{\a_1, ..., \a_n\right\}\in F_{\overline p}$ such that
$$
K \subset \sU_{\a_1} \cup ... \cup \sU_{\a_n}.
$$
It follows that 
\be\label{top_p_max_eqn}
p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) }\le \max_{j = 1,..., n} p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K_{\a_j}\right) }.
\ee 
Comparison of the equations \eqref{top_pk_eqn} and \eqref{top_p_max_eqn} yields the following
\be\label{top_pkp_eqn}
C^*\left(G, R\right)=\varprojlim_{K \in F_{\overline p}} C_b\left(\overline \sY \right)_{p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) }}
\ee




\end{empt}
\begin{theorem}\label{top_pro_thm}
	Consider the situation \ref{top_pro_empt}. Let $\widetilde \sX$ be the topological inverse limit of the given by \eqref{top_sbt_eqn}  pointed topological finite covering category and let $\widetilde p: \widetilde \sX\to\sX$ be the natural covering. Let $$\left(C\left( \bt\sX\right), C_0\left( \widetilde \sX\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde \sX\right|\bt \sX \right) \right)$$ be the inverse noncommutative limit of pointed algebraic finite covering category  $\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(\bt\sX \right) }$ given by \eqref{top_csbt_eqn}. 
	Then the triple 
	$$
	\left(C_F\left(\sX \right), C_{\widetilde p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}  \left(\widetilde \sX\right),G\left(\left.\widetilde \sX\right| \sX \right) \right)  
	$$
	is the inverse noncommutative limit of the given by \eqref{top_pro_cat_eqn} {pointed algebraical  finite covering category of pro-$C^*$-algebras} $\mathfrak{S}_{C_F\left(\sX \right) }$. (cf. Definition \ref{inv_pro_lim_defn})
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Let $C^*\left(G, R\right)=\varprojlim_{K \in F_{\overline p}} C_b\left(\overline \sY \right)_{p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) }}$
be given by \eqref{top_pkp_eqn}. 
$C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)$ is dense in  $C_0\left(\widetilde \sY \right)$ so the closure of $C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)$ in $C^*_r\left(G,R\right)$ coincides with closure of $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY \right)$ with respect to the family $\left\{p_{\widetilde K}\right\}_{\widetilde K\in \widetilde p^{-1}\left( F_{\overline p}\right) }$. Otherwise one has
\be\label{top_comps_eqn}
p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) }\left( \widetilde{a}\right) = p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) \cap \supp  \widetilde{a} }\left( \widetilde{a}\right)\quad  \forall \widetilde a\in  C_c\left( \widetilde \sY \right)
\ee
Let us prove that the set  $\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) \cap \supp  \widetilde{a}\subset \sX$ is compact. 
Similarly to \eqref{top_xina_eqn} consider inclusions 
$	\sU \subset K \subset \sV$ where $\sV$ is a connected open set evenly covered by $\overline p$ (cf. Definition \ref{comm_cov_pr_defn}). There is a connected open set $\overline \sU \subset \overline \sX$ which homeomorphically mapped onto $\overline p\left(\overline\sU \right)= \sU$. 
If $\overline G \bydef G\left(\left.\overline \sX\right|\sX\right)$ then $\overline p^{-1}\left(\sU \right) = \bigsqcup_{g \in \overline G}g \overline \sU$. If $\overline K \subset \overline\sU$ is such that $\overline p\left( \overline K\right)= K$ then $\overline K \cong K$ so $\overline K$ is compact. 
If the set
\bean
\overline G' \bydef \left\{\left.g \in \overline G\right| g \overline K \cap \supp  \widetilde{a}\neq \emptyset \right\}\subset \overline G,\\
\overline G'' \bydef \left\{\left.g \in G\overline G\right| g \overline \sU \cap \supp  \widetilde{a}\neq \emptyset \right\}\subset \overline G
\eean
then $\overline G' \subset \overline G''$
Otherwise from
$$
\supp  \widetilde{a} \subset \left(\sqcup_{g \in \overline G''}g \overline \sU \right)\bigcap \left(\widetilde \sX \setminus \widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right) \right)  
$$
and compactness of $\supp  \widetilde{a}$ if follows that the set $\overline G''$ is finite. So $\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)\cap \supp  \widetilde{a}$ is a finite union
$$
 \widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)\cap \supp  \widetilde{a} = \bigcup_{g \in \overline G'}g \overline K'\cap \supp  \widetilde{a}
$$
of compact set, i.e. $\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)\cap \supp  \widetilde{a}$ is compact. Otherwise 
$$
p_{\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)}\left(\widetilde{a} \right) = p_{\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K\right)  \cap \supp  \widetilde{a}}\left(\widetilde{a} \right) 
$$
Taking into account that $\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K\right)  \cap \supp  \widetilde{a}\in \overline p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c$  one has
$$
\forall \widetilde{a} \in C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)\quad \forall K \in F_{\overline p}\quad \exists \widetilde K \in \widetilde p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c \quad  p_{\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)} \left( \widetilde{a}\right) = p_{\widetilde K}\left(\widetilde a\right),
$$ it follows that the completion of  $C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)$ with respect to the family $\left\{p_{\widetilde p^{-1} \left(K \right)}\right\}_{K \in F_{\overline p}}$ coincides with the completion of $C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)$ with respect to the family $\left\{p_{\widetilde K }\right\}_{\widetilde K \in \overline p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}$ so one has
$$
\widetilde A =\varprojlim C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)_{p_{\overline p^{-1} \left( K\right) ~ K \in F} }\varprojlim C_c\left( \widetilde \sY\right)_{p_{\overline K}~ \K \in \overline p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}
$$
or equivalently
$$
\widetilde A = \varprojlim_{p_{\widetilde K}~\widetilde K \in \widetilde p^{-1}\left(F_c \right)} C\left( K\right). 
$$
Applying the Lemma \ref{comm_pro_lim}  one has $\widetilde A\cong C_{\widetilde p^{-1}\left(F \right)_c}  \left(\widetilde \sX\right)$.
\end{proof}


\subsection{Coverings of $O^*$-algebras and quasi $*$-algebras}\label{top_inf_o_sec}
\paragraph*{}
Let $M$ be an finite-dimensional smooth manifold, and let 

\be\label{top_secm_p_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }\bydef\\
	\bydef \left\{\left\{p_\la:\left( M_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( M, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}, \left\{p^\mu_{ \nu}:\left( M_\mu, x^\mu_0\right) \to \left( M_\nu, x^\nu_0\right)\right\}_{\substack{\mu,\nu\in\La\\
			\mu\ge\nu}} \right\}\\
	%\in \\
	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }\in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\text{pt}}.
\end{split}
\ee
be a pointed  topological finite covering category  (cf. Definition \ref{top_sec_p_defn}). From the Theorem \ref{top_d_fin_thm} it turns out that there is  a {pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by
\be\label{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{D\left(M \right) } = \left(\left\{\pi_\la: D\left( M\right)  \hookto D\left( M_\la \right) \right\}, \left\{\pi^\mu_\nu\right\}\right).
\end{split}
\ee
such that  $D\left( M_\la \right)$ is a *-algebra of differential operators $P:\Coo\left( M_\la\right) \to \Coo\left( M_\la\right)$  on $M_\la$  (cf. Definition \ref{do_man_defn})   for all $\la\in\La$. Note that for every $\la\in\La$ the smooth structure of $M_\la$ comes from the smooth structure on $M$ and the covering $M_\la\to M$. Injective *-homomorphisms $\pi_\la: D\left( M \right)\hookto D\left( M_\la \right)$ and $\pi^\nu_\mu: D\left( M_\nu \right)\hookto D\left( M_\mu \right)$ come from the coverings $p_\la$ and $p^\mu_\nu$ respectively.  If $\overline M$ is the disconnected inverse limit of $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}) then there are natural coverings $\overline p: \overline M\to M$, $\overline p_\la: \overline M\to M_\la$ which induce the structure of smooth manifold on $\overline M$. So for all $\la \in \La$ there is a natural injective *-homomorphism $D\left( M_\la \right)\hookto D\left(\overline M_\la \right)$. If these injective *-homomorphisms are regarded as inclusions and $\widehat A \bydef \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)$ then there is the following inclusion
\be\label{top_dinc_eqn}
\widehat A\hookto D\left( \overline M \right)
\ee
Let $\tau : C_0\left(M \right) \to \C$ be a faithful state  and let $L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ be explained in  \eqref{top_mu_empt} Hilbert space. 
Then 
\be\label{top_tdd_eqn}
\widehat \D\bydef  \Coo_c\left(\overline M \right)
\ee
 is a dense subspace of $L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$. There is the natural inclusion
\be D\left( \overline M\right) \subset \L^\dagger\left(\widehat\D \right)
\ee and taking into account  \eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn}  one has an inclusion 
\be\label{top_pi_eqn}
\pi: \widehat A\hookto \L^\dagger\left(\widehat\D \right).
\ee
If $\widehat G \bydef \varprojlim G\left(\left.M_\la\right|M\right)$ is the inverse limit then the natural action $\widehat G\times \overline M\to \overline M$ induces the action $\widehat G\times L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)\to L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ which satisfies to \eqref{o*_dinv_eqn}. Similarly to the Section \ref{top_pd_fin_sec} the bounded part of $D\left( M_\la\right)$ equals to $\Coo\left(M_\la \right) \cap C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ where we natural inclusion $\Coo \left(M_\la \right)\subset  D\left( M_\la\right)$ is implied. The $C^*$-norm completion of  $\Coo\left(M_\la \right) \cap C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ equals to $C_b\left(M_\la \right)$ and $B_\la \bydef C_0\left(M_\la \right)$ is an essential ideal of $C_b\left(M_\la \right)$. Similarly to  \eqref{bl_cat_eqn}
one has  a pointed algebraical  finite covering category
\be\label{top_bl_cat_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_b\bydef\left\{ \left( B ,  B_{\la} , G\left(\left.M_\la~\right|M \right) , \overline\pi_{\la}\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La}= \\ =\left\{ \left(C_0\left(M \right)  ,  C_0\left( M_{\la}\right)  , G\left(\left.M_\la~\right|M \right) , \overline\pi_{\la}\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La}.
\end{split}
\ee
If $\widehat B\bydef C^*$-$\varinjlim B_\la$ then there is the natural equivariant representation $\pi_\tau: \widehat{B}\hookto B\left( L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)\right)$. From the Theorem \ref{comm_main_mu_thm} it turns out  that the given by \eqref{top_bl_cat_eqn} pointed algebraical  finite covering category is $\pi_\tau$-good and if $\widetilde M$ is a topological inverse limit of $	\mathfrak{S}_{\left( M, x_0\right) }$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn} of then the triple\\ $\left(C_0\left(M\right), C_0\left(\widetilde M\right),G\left(\left.\widetilde M~\right| M\right)\right)$ is  the  $\pi_\tau$-infinite noncommutative covering of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_b$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn} and Theorem \ref{comm_main_mu_thm}). If $\widetilde \H$ is the norm completion of $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)L^2\left(\overline M, \overline \mu\right)$ then one has
\be
\begin{split}
	\widetilde \H \cong L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde\mu\bydef \overline\mu|_{\widetilde M}\right) ,\\
	\widetilde \D\bydef \widehat\D \cap \widetilde \H \cong \Coo_c\left( \widetilde M\right) 
\end{split}
\ee
Above construction is a version of the described in \ref{comp_pt_o*_empt} general construction.

\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_o*_thm}
	In the described above situation if $\pi$ is given by \eqref{top_pi_eqn} then the triple
	$\left(D\left(M \right) , D\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right)\right) $ is the 
	${\pi}$- inverse noncommutative limit (cf. Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn}) of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{D\left( M\right) }$ a {pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by
	\eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
	For any $\la\in\La$ denote by $\widetilde p_\la: \widetilde{M}\to M$ the natural covering. 
	Let us prove that $D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ is $\pi$-admissible, i.e. it satisfies to the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}; that is
	\bea\label{top_inv_o*_lim_eqn}
	G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right) D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  = D\left( \widetilde{M}\right),\\
	\label{top_inv_o*_blim_eqn}
	\widetilde A'_b\bydef C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \cap \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \subset M\left(\widetilde{B}_{\pi_\tau}= M\left( C_0\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)  \right)\cong C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right), \\
	\label{top_inv_o*_llim_eqn}	
	\mathrm{span}~\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)= \mathrm{span}~\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\left(  \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right) ,\\	
	\label{top_inv_o*_rlim_eqn}
	\mathrm{span}~D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  = \mathrm{span}~\left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right).	
	\eea
	\begin{itemize}
		\item The equation \eqref{top_inv_o*_lim_eqn} holds because any $g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right)$ corresponds to a diffeomorphism of $\widetilde{M}$.
		\item The equation \eqref{top_inv_o*_blim_eqn} follows from an evident dense inclusion $C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \cap \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \subset C_b\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$.
		\item From $  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\subset  \left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right)$ it follows that $\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right)$
		
		
		The equation  \eqref{top_inv_o*_llim_eqn} 
		Let  $\widetilde f \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ and $\widetilde d \in  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$. There is $\widetilde h \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ such that $\widetilde h\left(\supp \widetilde f \right)= \{1\}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la\in\La$ such that $\supp \widetilde h$ is homeomorphically mapped onto $\widetilde p_\la\left(\supp\widetilde h \right)$. If $d_\la \bydef \desc_{\widetilde p_\la} \left(\widetilde h \widetilde d \right)$ then  $\widetilde f \widetilde d= \widetilde f d_\la$.
		\item The equation  \eqref{top_inv_o*_rlim_eqn} follows from $  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\Coo_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)\subset  \left( \bigcup_{\la \in \La}D\left( M_\la \right)\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$.
		Let  $\widetilde f \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ and $\widetilde d \in  D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$. There is $\widetilde h \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ such that $\widetilde h\left(\supp \widetilde f \right)= \{1\}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la\in\La$ such that $\supp \widetilde h$ is homeomorphically mapped onto $\widetilde p_\la\left(\supp\widetilde h \right)$. If $d_\la \bydef \desc_{\widetilde p_\la} \left(\widetilde d \widetilde h \right)$ then  $\widetilde d \widetilde f= d_\la \widetilde f$.
		
	\end{itemize}
	Now one should prove that $D\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ is a maximal *-algebra which satisfies to  the equations \eqref{inv_o*_lim_eqn}-\eqref{inv_o*_rlim_eqn}. If it is not maximal then there is an admissible *-subalgebra $\widetilde A'\subset \L^\dagger\left( \widetilde \D\right)$ and  $\widetilde d \in \widetilde A'\setminus D\left(\widetilde M \right)$. Since  $\widetilde d \notin  D\left(\widetilde M \right)$ there is $\widetilde f \in \Coo\left(\widetilde M \right)$ such that $\supp\widetilde d \widetilde f \not\subset\supp\widetilde f$ (cf Definition \ref{do_man_defn}). There is $\widetilde h \in \Coo_c\left(\widetilde M  \right)$ such that $\widetilde h\left( \supp \widetilde d \widetilde f \setminus\supp \widetilde f\right)   \neq \{0\}$. It follows that $\supp \widetilde h \widetilde d\widetilde f\not\subset \supp\widetilde f$. So one has
	\be\label{top_inv_o*_llim_n_eqn}
	\widetilde h \widetilde d \not\in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde M\right) D\left( M_\la\right)\quad \forall\la\in\La.
	\ee
However the equation \eqref{top_inv_o*_llim_n_eqn} contradicts with the equation \eqref{inv_o*_llim_eqn}. From this contradiction it follows that $D\left(\widetilde M \right)$ is maximal among admissible subalgebras.
\end{proof}
Similarly to \eqref{top_comp_pt_o*_eqn} one has 
{pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by
\be\label{top_comps_pt_o*_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right) } = \left(\left\{\pi_\la: \Coo\left( M\right)  \hookto \Coo\left( M_\la \right) \right\}, \left\{\pi^\mu_\nu\right\}\right).
\end{split}
\ee
Similarly to the Theorem \ref{top_inf_o*_thm}
one can proof the following Theorem
\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_o*_m_thm}
	In the described above situation the triple\\
	$\left(\Coo\left(M \right) ,\Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}\right|M\right)\right) $ is the 
	${\pi}|_{\bigcup_{\la \in \La}\Coo\left( M_\la \right)}$-\textit{ inverse noncommutative limit of $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right) }$} a {pointed algebraic finite covering category of $O^*$-algebras} (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn}) given by
	\eqref{top_comps_pt_o*_eqn}
\end{theorem}
\begin{remark}
	The Theorem \ref{top_inf_o*_m_thm} is a noncommutative counterpart of the Proposition \ref{top_cov_mani_prop}. 
\end{remark}

\begin{theorem}\label{top_inf_q*_thm}
	In situation \ref{top_comp_qo*_empt} the triple
	$$
\left(\left(\Coo_c\left(M \right)', \Coo\left(M \right)    \right), \left(\Coo_c\left(\widetilde M \right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde M \right)    \right), G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\right)

\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
	
	Firstly note that the specific version of the equations \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} -\eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} is presented below
	\bea
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~\quad\quad \\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_lzero_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in  \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \widetilde{a}\Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) = \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~ \quad\quad\\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_llim_eqn}	\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)  \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\right\rbrace =\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\rbrace,~\quad\quad \\	
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rlim_eqn}\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace 	 \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\rbrace =\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\rbrace.~\quad\quad 
	\eea
	If  $\left\{f_\a\right\}_{\a\in \mathscr A}\subset C_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right)$ is  a family of functions is a given by the  \eqref{comm_direct_empt} then for any compact $\widetilde{\sY}\subset \widetilde{M}$ there is $\a_{\widetilde{\sY}}$ such that for all $\a\ge \a_{\widetilde{\sY}}$ one has $\widetilde f_\a\left( \widetilde \sY\right) = \{1\}$ (cf. Lemma \ref{comm_direct_lem}). From the Proposition \ref{top_smooth_part_unity_prop} one can assume that $\left\{\widetilde f_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)_+$. If $\left( \widetilde{\mathfrak A}', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) $ is an admissible quasi *-algebra (cf. Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}) then from the equation \ref{inv_qo*_llim_eqn} which in this specialization is equivalent to \ref{top_inv_qo*_llim_eqn}  it follows that
	$$
\forall \widetilde a\in \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\quad \forall \a\in \mathscr A\quad	\widetilde f_\a\widetilde a \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\left( \bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) .
	$$
	On the other hand from $\bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ it turns out that $\widetilde f_\a \widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$.  For any  $\widetilde b \in \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)$ one has
	\be\label{top_sw_lim_eqn}
\a\ge \a_{\supp b}\quad \Rightarrow \quad 	\left\langle \widetilde f_\a\widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle = 	\left\langle \widetilde f_{\a_{\supp b}} \widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle
\ee
where $\left\langle \cdot , \cdot \right\rangle: \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\times \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\to \C$ is the natural pairing.
The equation \eqref{top_sw_lim_eqn} means that the net $ \left\lbrace \left\langle \widetilde f_\a\widetilde a , \widetilde b \right\rangle\right\rbrace $ is convergent, so the net  $ \left\lbrace \widetilde f_\a \widetilde a\right\rbrace $ is convergent with respect to the weak topology of $\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$. Thus there is a map
\bean
\Psi : \widetilde{\mathfrak A}'\to \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)',\\
\widetilde a\mapsto\lim_{\a\in \mathscr A} \widetilde f_\a \widetilde a
\eean 
 If $\widetilde a\in \ker \Psi$ then $\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\widetilde a= \{0\}$ so from \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} (or equivalently \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzero_eqn}) it follows that $\widetilde a=0$. So one has $\ker \Psi = \{0\}$, $\Psi$ is an invective map and any admissible *- algebra $\left( \widetilde{\mathfrak A}', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) $ is a quasi *-subalgebra  of 
$\left( \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$.  Thus if we prove that  $\left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ is admissible then the proof of this lemma would be completed (cf. Definition \ref{inv_qo*_lim_defn}). It means that $\left( \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ satisfies to the conditions (a)-(c) of the Definition \ref{comp_pt_qo*_defn}.
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] The action $G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\times \widetilde M\to \widetilde M$ naturally induces the action $G\left(\left. \widetilde M\right| M\right)\times \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)\to \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$.
	\item[(b)] The existence of injective *-homomorphism 
	$$
	\varphi: \bigcup_{\La \in \la} \left( \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)', \Coo\left( {M}_\la\right)\right)\hookto \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right) 
	$$ 
	follows from the natural inclusions $ \left( \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)', \Coo\left( {M}_\la\right)\right)\hookto \left( \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)', \Coo\left( \widetilde{M}\right)\right)$ for all $\la\in\La$.
	\item[(c)]  The specific version of equations \eqref{inv_qo*_rzero_eqn} -\eqref{inv_qo*_rlim_eqn} is presented below

		\bea
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'\quad \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~\quad\quad \\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_lzerop_eqn}
	\forall\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'\quad \widetilde{a}\Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) = \{0\}\quad \Rightarrow\quad \widetilde{a}= 0,~ \quad\quad\\
	\label{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn}	\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\rbrace =\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\rbrace,~\quad\quad \\	
	\label{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn}\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace 	\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\rbrace =\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \right\rbrace~\quad\quad 
	\eea
	so one needs check equations
 \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn} -\eqref{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn}.
Suppose that $\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)'$ is such that $\Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right) \widetilde{a}= \{0\}$. For all  $\widetilde a\in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)$, there is $ \widetilde{c} \in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)_+$ such that $\widetilde{c}\left( \supp \widetilde{b}\right) = \{1\}$. It follows that 
$$
\left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde b \right\rangle = \left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde{c}\widetilde b \right\rangle = \left\langle \widetilde a \widetilde{c},\widetilde b \right\rangle,
$$
so if $\widetilde a \widetilde{c}=0$ then $\left\langle \widetilde a, \widetilde b \right\rangle= 0$. Thus the equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn} is proven. The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_lzerop_eqn}  is equivalent to \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rzerop_eqn}.  From $\bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\subset \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'$ it follows that 
\be\label{top_cc_l_inc_eqn}
\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\rbrace\subset \mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\rbrace 
\ee
If  $\widetilde a \in \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde b \in \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'$, then there is $ \widetilde{c} \in \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right)_+$ such that $\widetilde{c}\left( \supp \widetilde{a}\right) = \{1\}$. It follows that $\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}= \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}$. From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la\in\La$ such that $\supp \widetilde{c}$ is homeomorphically mapped onto  $\widetilde p_\la\left(\supp \widetilde{c} \right) $, where  $\widetilde p_\la: \widetilde M\to M_\la$ is the natural covering. It turns out that there is the descent of 
$\desc_{\widetilde p_\la}\left(\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a} \right) \in  \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'$ such that 
$$
\widetilde{b}\desc_{\widetilde p_\la}\left(\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a} \right) =\widetilde{b}\widetilde{c}\widetilde{a}.
$$
It follows that 
\be\label{top_cc_r_inc_eqn}
\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right) \Coo_c\left( \widetilde{M}\right)'\right\rbrace \subset\mathrm{span}\left\lbrace  \Coo_c\left(  \widetilde{M}\right) \left( \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \Coo_c\left( {M}_\la\right)'\right) \right\rbrace
\ee	
The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn} follows from \eqref{top_cc_l_inc_eqn} and \eqref{top_cc_r_inc_eqn}. The equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_rlimp_eqn} is equivalent to the equation \eqref{top_inv_qo*_llimp_eqn}.
\end{enumerate}

\end{proof}

\begin{exercise}
	Let $M$ be a smooth manifold and let $p:\widetilde M\to M$ be a transitive infinite covering such that the covering group $G\left(\left. \widetilde{   M } ~\right| {   M }\right)$ is residually finite (cf. Definition \ref{residually_finite_defn}). Let $E\to M$ be a smooth bundle, and $\widetilde E\to  \widetilde M$ is the inverse image of $E$ by $p$ (cf. Definition \ref{vb_inv_img_funct_defn}). Let $D\left(M, E \right)$ and  $D\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde E \right)$)  be an $O^*$-algebra of differential operators \ref{do_man_defn} such that 
	\bean
	D\left( M,   E \right)= \left\{P: \Coo\left(M, E \right)\to \Coo\left(M, E \right)\right\},\\
	D\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde E \right)= \left\{\widetilde P: \Coo\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde E \right)\to \Coo\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde E \right)\right\}
	\eean
	Prove that there is an equivariant representation $\pi: C^*$-$\varinjlim_{\la \in \La}C_0\left( M_\la\right)\to B\left( \H\right)$  
	a $\pi$-{noncommutative finite-fold covering of $O^*$-algebras} given by
	(cf. Definition \ref{fino*_defn})
	$$
	\left(D\left(M, E \right),D\left(  \widetilde{   M }, \widetilde E\right) ,G\left(\left. \widetilde{   M } ~\right| {   M }\right)\right)
	$$
\end{exercise}
\subsection{Induced representations}\label{comm_induced_infinite_sec}

\paragraph*{} 
Similarly to the section \ref{comm_induced_finite_sec} consider a compact  Riemannian manifold $M$ with a  spinor bundle $S$ (cf. \ref{comm_sp_tr_sec}). 
Let $\tau:C\left( M\right) \to \C$ be a faithful state such that 
$$
\tau\left(a \right) = \int_{M} a~ d\mu
$$
Similarly to the Section \ref{comm_induced_finite_sec} there is a Hilbert space $ L^2\left(  M, S\right)\cong  L^2\left(  M, S, \mu\right)$ and   the natural representation
\be\label{comm_m_bundle_inf_repr_eqn}
\rho: C\left(M\right) \to B\left( L^2\left(  M, S\right)\right). 
\ee
 Let $p: \widetilde M \to M$ be an infinite transitive covering, such that the group $G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)$ is residually finite. From the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} and the  Theorem \ref{comm_main_thm} it turns out that the triple  $\left(C\left( M\right) , C_0\left( \widetilde M\right) G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)\right)$ is an infinite noncommutative covering (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). Similarly to \eqref{top_ot_eqn} one can construct a functional
\bean
\widetilde\tau: C_c\left(\widetilde M \right) \to \C. 
\eean 
 Define the $\C$-valued product
\be
\begin{split}
	\left( \cdot, \cdot \right): \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)\times \Ga_c\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S\right) \to \C,\\
	\left(\widetilde\xi,\widetilde \eta \right) \mapsto \widetilde \tau\left( \left\langle\widetilde\xi, \widetilde\eta \right\rangle_c \right) 
\end{split}
\ee
where the pairing $	\left\langle \cdot, \cdot \right\rangle_c:  \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)\times \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)\to C_c\left(\widetilde M \right) $ is given by \eqref{top_ggc_eqn}.
This product yields the structure of pre-Hilbert space on $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)$. Denote by $ L^2\left(\widetilde  M,\widetilde S\right)\cong  L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S, \widetilde \mu\right)$ the Hilbert norm completion of $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)$. The natural action $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right) \times \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,\widetilde S\right)\to \Ga_c\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde S\right)$ induces  the natural representation
\be\label{comm_bundlei_repr_eqn}
C_0\left(\widetilde M\right) \to B\left( L^2\left(\widetilde  M, \widetilde S\right)\right). 
\ee 

\begin{lemma}\label{comm_allows_lem}
	If $\mathfrak{S}_{\left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) } = \left\{\left( \mathcal{X}_\la,x_0^\la\right)  \to \left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) \right\}_{\la \in \La} \in \mathfrak{FinTop}^{\mathrm{pt}}$, \\
	$\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right) }\left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) =
	\left( \left\{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}\right) \hookto  C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\la\right) \right\}, \left\{C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\mu\right) \hookto  C_0\left( \mathcal{X}_\nu\right) \right\} \right) $ then $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right) }$ allows inner product (cf. Definition \ref{inf_hilb_prod_defn}). 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	%	Denote by $G_\la = G\left(\mathcal X_\la~|~\mathcal X \right)$ groups of covering transformations and $\widehat{G} = \varprojlim G_\la$. 
	Denote by $\overline{p}:\left( \overline{  \mathcal X}, \overline x_0\right)  \to\left(  \mathcal X, x_0\right) $, $\overline{p}_\la:\left( \overline{  \mathcal X}, \overline x_0\right)  \to\left(  \mathcal X_\la, x^\la_0\right) $, $p^\la: \left(  \mathcal X_\la, x^\la_0\right)  \to \left( \mathcal X, x_0\right) $, $p^\mu_\nu:  \left( \mathcal X_\mu, x^\mu_0 \right) \to \left( \mathcal X_\nu, x^\nu_0\right) $ ($\mu > \nu$) the natural pointed coverings.
	If $\widetilde{\sX}= \varprojlim \mathfrak{S}_{\left(\sX, x_0 \right)}$ then  	from the Theorem \ref{comm_main_thm} it turns out	
	$$\left(C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right), C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX}\right),G\left(\widetilde{\sX}~|~ \mathcal X\right)\right)$$ is  the  { infinite noncommutative covering} of $\mathfrak{S}_{C_0\left(\mathcal{X}\right)}$ (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). 	 	It is shown in \cite{pedersen:mea_c} that the Pedersen's ideal $K\left(C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)\right) $ of $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ coincides with $C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$. If $\widetilde{a}, \widetilde{b} \in C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ then $\supp \overline{a}$ is compact. 	
	From the Lemma \ref{top_comp_la_lem} it follows that there is $\la_0 \in \La$ such that for all $\la \ge \la_0$ the restriction $\left.\overline{p}_\la\right|_{\supp \overline{a}}$ is injective. From (ii) of the Lemma  \ref{comm_lift_desc_sum_lem} it follows that
	\begin{equation}\nonumber
		\begin{split}
			c_{\la} = \sum_{g \in \ker\left(G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX \right)  \to  G\left( \sX_{\la}~|~\sX \right)\right)} g \left(\widetilde{a}^* \widetilde{b}  \right) = \desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right) 
		\end{split}
	\end{equation}
	where notation  $\desc_{\overline{p}_\la}$ means  the descent	(cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}). From the properties of the descent it turns out that $\desc_{\overline{p}_\la}\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right) \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$, i.e. $c_\la \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$.  Taking into account the Remark \ref{inf_hilb_prod_low_rem} we conclude that  $c_\la \in C_0\left( \sX_{\la}\right)$ for all $\la \in \La$.
\end{proof}
From the Lemma \ref{comm_allows_lem} it follows that the  induced by $\left(\rho, \left(C\left( M\right) , C_0\left( \widetilde M\right) G\left(\left.\widetilde M   ~\right| M\right)\right)\right)$ representation $\widetilde \rho: C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\hookto B\left( \widetilde \H\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{induced_repr_inf_defn}), such that $\widetilde \H$ is the Hilbert norm completion of
$$
K\left( C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\right)\otimes_{C\left( {M}\right)} L^2\left(  M, S\right)
$$
where $K\left( C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)\right)$ is Pedersen's ideal of $C_0\left( \widetilde M\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{peder_id_defn} and Remark \ref{ap_act_hilb_rem}). On the other hand 	it is proven in \cite{pedersen:mea_c} that the Pedersen's ideal $K\left(C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)\right) $ of $C_0\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$ coincides with $C_c\left(\widetilde{\sX} \right)$.  If
$$
\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)\bydef C_c\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(M, \left\{S_x\right\}, \Ga\left(M, S\right)\right)\right]\right)  
$$
then from the Lemma \ref{top_tensor_lcompact_lem} it follows that there is the given by \eqref{top_tensor_lccompact_iso_eqn} isomorphism
$$
C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)}\Ga\left(M,S \right) \xrightarrow{\approx}\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)
$$
of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M \right)$-modules. On the other hand 
then from \ref{top_herm_bundle_empt} it follows that there is the dense with respect to the Hilbert norm inclusion $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)\subset L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)$, hence there is  the homomorphism
\be\label{top_lift_g_inf_eqn}
\phi: C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)}\Ga\left(M,S \right) \to L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)
\ee
of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M \right)$-modules.
\begin{lemma}\label{top_hilb_inf_lem}
	Following conditions hold:
	\begin{itemize}
		\item [(i)] The map \eqref{top_lift_g_inf_eqn} can be extended up to the following homomorphism 
		$$
		C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right) \xrightarrow{\approx} L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)
		$$
		of left $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$-modules.
		\item[(ii)] The image of $C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$.
	\end{itemize}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}(i)
	Let $\sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_j\in 	C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ be any element. From \ref{top_herm_bundle_empt}  it turns out that $L^2\left( M, S, \mu\right)$ is the Hilbert norm completion of $\Ga\left(M, \sS\right)$. Hence for any $j =1,..., n$ there is a net $\left\{\xi_{j\a}\right\}\subset \Ga\left(M, \sS\right)$ such that $\xi_j = \lim_\a \xi_{j\a}$ where we mean the convergence with respect to the Hilbert norm $\left\| \cdot\right\|_{L^2\left(M, \sS\right)}$. If $C = \max_{j = 1,...,n}\left\|\widetilde a_j\right\|$ then there is $\a_0$ such that
	$$
	\a \ge \a_0 \quad \Rightarrow \left\| \xi_j - \xi_{j\a}\right\|_{L^2\left(M, \sS\right)} < \frac{\eps}{nC},
	$$
	so one has
	$$
	\a \ge \a_0 \quad \Rightarrow \left\| \sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a_0} - \sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a}\right\|_{L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)} < \eps.
	$$
	The above equation it follows that the net $\left\{\sum_{j = 1}^n \widetilde a_j \otimes \xi_{j\a}\right\}_\a$ satisfies to the Cauchy condition, so it is convergent with respect to the topology of $L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)$.\\
	(ii) From the Lemma \eqref{top_tensor_lcompact_lem} it follows that the image of $C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)$ in $L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde\sS\right)$ contains $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$, however $\Ga_c\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$. It follows that  $\phi\left(  C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right)\right)$ is dense in $L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$. 
\end{proof}

\begin{empt} 
If $\widetilde{a} \otimes \xi, \widetilde{b} \otimes \eta \in C_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right) \otimes_{C\left(M \right) } \Ga\left( M, S\right) \subset L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)$  then $\supp \widetilde{a}$ is compact, so there exists a subordinated to $\widetilde p$ {covering sum} for $\supp \widetilde{a}$ (cf. Definitions \ref{top_cfs_defn} and \ref{top_cfs_sub_defn}) 
\bean
\sum_{\widetilde \a\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}} \widetilde a_{\widetilde\a}.
\eean
where a given by \eqref{top_cfsa_eqn} notation  is used. If $\widetilde e_\a \bydef \sqrt{\widetilde a_\a}$ and $e_\a = \desc_{\widetilde p}\left( \widetilde e_\a\right) $ means $\widetilde p$-descent (cf. Definition \ref{top_lift_desc_defn}) then from \eqref{top_desc_fin_eqn} it turns out that
$$
\forall\a\in \mathscr A \quad \widetilde a_\a = \widetilde e_\a e_\a.
$$

The given by the equation \eqref{comp_hilb_eqn} scalar product $\left(\cdot, \cdot \right)_{\text{ind}}$ on  $C_c\left(\widetilde{M} \right) \otimes_{C\left(M \right) } \Ga\left( M, S\right)$ satisfies to the following equation
\begin{equation}\label{comm_ind_l2_lc_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\left( \widetilde{a} \otimes \xi ,    \widetilde{b} \otimes \eta\right)_{\text{ind}}= \left(\xi, \left\langle \widetilde{a}, \widetilde{b}\right\rangle_{C\left(\widetilde{M} \right) } \eta \right)_{L^2\left({M},{S} \right)}=\\=\sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}\left(\xi, \left\langle \widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde{a}, \widetilde{b}\right\rangle_{C\left(\widetilde{M} \right) } \eta \right)_{L^2\left({M},{S} \right)}=
		\\
		= \sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}\left(\xi, \mathfrak{desc}\left( \widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}} \widetilde{a}^* \widetilde{b}\right)  \eta \right)_{L^2\left({M},{S} \right)}=
		\\
		=
		\sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}~\int_M \left(\xi_x, \mathfrak{desc}\left( \widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}} \widetilde{a}^* \widetilde{b}\right)  \eta_x \right)_x d\mu=
		\\
		=
		\sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}~\int_M \left(\mathfrak{desc}\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} \widetilde{a}\right)\xi_x, \mathfrak{desc}\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}  \widetilde{b}\right)  \eta_x \right)_x d\mu=
		\\
		=\sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}~ \int_{\widetilde{M}}\left(\widetilde{a} \lift_{\widetilde{\sU}_{\widetilde{\a}}}\left({e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\xi \right)_{\widetilde{x}},  \widetilde{b} ~\lift_{\widetilde{\sU}_{\widetilde{\a}}}\left({e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\eta \right)_{\widetilde{x}}\right)_{\widetilde{x}}d \widetilde{   \mu} =
		\\
		=\sum_{\widetilde{\a}\in \widetilde{\mathscr A}_{\supp \widetilde{a}}}~ \int_{\widetilde{M}}\widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{\a}}\left(\widetilde{a} \lift_{\widetilde{\sU}_{\widetilde{\a}}}\left(\xi \right)_{\widetilde{x}},  \widetilde{b} ~\lift_{\widetilde{\sU}_{\widetilde{\a}}}\left(\eta \right)_{\widetilde{x}}\right)_{\widetilde{x}}d \widetilde{   \mu} =
		\\
		= \int_{\widetilde{M}}\left( \widetilde{a} \lift_p\left(\xi \right)_{\widetilde{x}},  \widetilde{b} ~\lift_p\left(\eta \right)_{\widetilde{x}}\right)_{\widetilde{x}}d \widetilde{   \mu}
		= \left( \widetilde{a}~ \lift_p\left(\xi \right),  \widetilde{b} ~\lift_p\left(\eta \right)\right)_{L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)} =\\
		=  \left(\phi\left(  \widetilde{a}\otimes\xi\right) ,  \phi \left( \widetilde{b}\otimes\eta\right)\right)_{L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)}
	\end{split} 
\end{equation}
where $\phi$ is given by \eqref{top_tensor_lccompact_iso_eqn}.
The equation \eqref{comm_ind_l2_lc_eqn} means that $\left(\cdot, \cdot \right)_{\text{ind}}= \left(\cdot, \cdot \right)_{L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)}$, and taking into account the dense inclusion $C\left(\widetilde{M} \right) \otimes_{C\left(M \right) } \Ga\left( M, S\right) \subset L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)$ with respect to the Hilbert norm of $L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S}\right) $
one concludes that the space of induced representation coincides with $L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S}\right)$. It means that induced representation $C\left(\widetilde{M}\right) \times L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right) \to L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)$ is given by \eqref{comm_bundle_repr_eqn}. So one has the following lemma.
\end{empt}
\begin{lemma}\label{comm_ind_lc_lem}
	If the representation  $\widetilde{\rho}: C\left(\widetilde{M}\right) \to  B\left( \widetilde{   \H}\right)  $ is induced by the pair $$\left(C\left(M \right)\to B\left(  L^2\left(M,S \right)\right) ,\left(C\left(M \right) , C_0\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , G\left( \left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M\right) \right)  \right)$$ (cf. Definition \ref{induced_repr_inf_defn}) then following conditions hold:
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item[(a)] There is the homomorphism of Hilbert spaces $\widetilde{   \H}\cong L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)$,
		\item[(b)] The representation $\widetilde{\rho}$ is given by the natural action of $C_0\left(\widetilde{M}\right)$ on $ L^2\left(\widetilde{M},\widetilde{S} \right)$ (cf. \ref{comm_bundlei_repr_eqn}).
	\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	(a) Follows from \eqref{comm_ind_l2_lc_eqn},\\
	(b) From the Lemma \ref{top_hilb_homo_lem}  it follows that the map 		$	C_c\left(\widetilde M\right)\otimes_{C\left(M\right)} L^2\left(M, \sS\right) \xrightarrow{\approx} L^2\left(\widetilde{M}, \widetilde{\SS} \right)$ is the homomorphism of $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$ modules, so the given by \eqref{comm_bundle_repr_eqn} $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$-action coincides with the $C_0\left(\widetilde M\right)$-action  the given by \eqref{comp_hilb_actf_eqn}.
\end{proof}



\subsection{Coverings of spectral triples}
\paragraph*{} Let $\left(C^{\infty}\left( M\right) , L^2\left( M, S\right) ,\slashed D\right)$ be a commutative spectral triple (cf. equation \eqref{comm_sp_tr_eqn}), and let $p:\widetilde{M} \to M$ be an infinite regular covering such that  the {covering group} $G\left( {\widetilde{M}}~|~M\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{cov_proj_cov_grp_defn}) is residually finite (cf. Definition \ref{residually_finite_defn}). From the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} it it turns out that there is a (topological)  finite covering category 
\be\label{top_m_cat_eqn}
\mathfrak{S} = \left\{p_\la: M_\la \to M\right\}
\ee
 (cf. \ref{top_sec_defn}) such that  the {(topological) inverse limit} of $\mathfrak{S}$ is naturally homeomorphic  to $\widetilde{M}$. From the Proposition \ref{comm_cov_mani_prop} it follows that $\widetilde{M}$ and $M_\la$ ($\forall \la \in \La$)  have natural structure of the Riemannian manifolds. According to the Example \ref{top_vb_lift_desc_exm} denote by $\widetilde{S}\stackrel{\mathrm{def}}{=} C_0\left( \lift_p\left(S \right) \right) $ and $S_\la \stackrel{\mathrm{def}}{=} C_b\left( \lift_{p_\la}\left( S\right) \right) $  (for all $\la \in \La$) the lifts of the spin bundle (cf. \ref{top_vb_sub_sub}). Similarly to \eqref{top_mo_eqn} we define the following operators
	\be\label{top_dlift_eqn}
\begin{split}
	 \Dslash_\la \bydef p^{-1}\Dslash\in \mathscr End\left( \mathscr  C^\infty\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right)\right)\left(  M_\la\right),\\
\widetilde	 \Dslash \bydef p^{-1}\Dslash\in \mathscr End\left( \mathscr  C^\infty\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde\sS \right)\right)\left( \widetilde M\right).
\end{split}
\ee
Otherwise from the equation \eqref{top_mod_eqn} it turns out that $\Dslash_\la$ and $\widetilde \Dslash$ can be regarded as $\C$-linear operators, i.e.
\bean
 \Dslash_\la :\Ga^\infty\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right)\to\Ga^\infty\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right),\\
\widetilde \Dslash :\Ga^\infty_c\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde\sS \right)\to\Ga^\infty_c\left(\widetilde M,  \widetilde\sS \right) .
\eean
Since both $\Ga^\infty\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right)$ and $\Ga^\infty_c\left(  \widetilde M,  \widetilde \sS \right)$ are dense in $L^2\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right)$ and $L^2\left(  \widetilde M,  \widetilde \sS \right)$ the operator  $\Dslash_\la$ and $\widetilde\Dslash$ are  unbounded operators on $L^2\left( M_\la,  \sS_\la \right)$ and $L^2\left(  \widetilde M,  \widetilde \sS \right)$. So there is a family 

\begin{equation}\label{comm_triple_seq_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\mathfrak{S}_{\left(C^{\infty}\left( M\right) , L^2\left( M, S\right) ,\slashed D\right) } = \left\{
		\left(C^{\infty}\left( M_\la\right) , L^2\left( M_\la, S_\la\right) ,p_\la^{-1} \slashed D\right)
		\right\}_{\la \in \La}
	\end{split}
\end{equation}
of spectral triples. Let $\overline M$ be the disconnected inverse limit of the given by \eqref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn} a (topological)  finite covering category 
\eqref{top_m_cat_eqn} and let $\overline S$ be the corresponding spinor bundle.
\begin{lemma}
The given by \eqref{comm_triple_seq_eqn} family $	\mathfrak{S}_{\left(C^{\infty}\left( M\right) , L^2\left( M, S\right) ,\slashed D\right) }$ is the coherent set of spectral triples (cf. Definition \ref{cov_sec_triple_defn}).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
	One needs check that $	\mathfrak{S}_{\left(C^{\infty}\left( M\right) , L^2\left( M, S\right) ,\slashed D\right) }$ satisfies to conditions (a)-(e) of the Definition \ref{cov_sec_triple_defn}.\\
	(a) Follows from the Theorem \ref{comm_fin_sp_tr_thm}.\\
	(b) $C\left( M_\la\right)$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $\Coo\left( M_\la\right)$ for all $\la\in\La$.\\
	(c) From the coverings $\overline M \to M_\la$ ($\la\in\La$) one can obtain a faithful representations $C\left(M_\la \right)\hookto B\left(L^2\left( \overline M, \overline S\right)  \right)$. These representations yield an equivariant representation $\pi: C^*$-$\varinjlim_{\la \in \La} C\left( M_\la\right)  \hookto B\left(L^2\left( \overline M, \overline S\right)\right) $ such that $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}$. Similarly to the proof of the Theorem \ref{comm_main_thm} one can prove that an {algebraical  finite covering category} $
	\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(M\right)}=
	\left\{C(M)\hookto C(M_\la)\right\}_{\la \in \La}
	$ is $\pi$-good (cf. Definition \ref{mains_defn}.)\\
	(d)  Follows from the Theorem \ref{comm_fin_sp_tr_thm}.\\
	(e)  Similarly to the proof of the Theorem \ref{comm_main_thm} one can prove that  $\pi$-algebraical infinite noncommutative covering  of $\mathfrak{S}_{C\left(M \right) }$ equals to $\left( C\left(M \right) , C_0\left( \widetilde M\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M \right) \right)$.
\end{proof}
\begin{empt}\label{top_reg_triple_empt}
Here we consider a specialization of the construction \ref{reg_triple_empt}. For any $\la\in\La$ denote by $\Coo\left(M_\la \right) _{\Dslash_\la}$ {extended algebra of the spectral triple} \\$\left(\Coo\left(M_\la \right), L^2\left( M_\la, S_\la\right), \Dslash_\la\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{ext_st_alg_defn}). Consider  a Hilbert space $\widetilde \H\bydef L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right) $, its dense subspace $\widetilde \D\bydef\Ga^\infty_c\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)\subset L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)$ and the inclusion 
$$
\rho_\Dslash:\bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo\left(M_\la \right) _{\Dslash_\la}\hookto \L^\dagger\left(\widetilde \D \right). 
$$
Similarly to Theorems \ref{top_inf_o*_thm} and \ref{top_inf_o*_m_thm} one can prove that there are
pointed algebraic finite covering categories of $O^*$-algebras (cf. Definition \ref{comp_o*_defn})
given by
\be\label{top_str_cat_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right)_{\Dslash}} = \left(\left\{\rho_\la: \Coo\left(M \right) _{\Dslash} \hookto \Coo\left(M_\la \right) _{\Dslash_\la} \right\}, \left\{\rho^\mu_\nu\right\}\right),\\
	\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right)} = \left(\left\{\left.\rho_\la\right|_{\Coo\left(M \right)}: \Coo\left(M \right) \hookto \Coo\left(M_\la \right)  \right\}, \left\{\left.\rho^\mu_\nu\right|_{\Coo\left(M_\mu \right)}\right\}\right).
\end{split}
\ee
Direct check shows that the natural action $G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M \right)\times L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)\to L^2\left( \widetilde M, \widetilde S\right)$ satisfies to the conditions \eqref{str_act_eqn}. Similarly to the proof of the Theorems \ref{top_inf_o*_thm} and \ref{top_inf_o*_m_thm} one can prove that there is   $\rho_\Dslash$ and $\left.\rho_\Dslash\right|_{\bigcup_{\la\in\La} \Coo\left(M_\la \right)}$-inverse noncommutative limits (cf. Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn})  of both $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right)_{\Dslash}}$ and $\mathfrak{S}^{\text{pt}}_{\Coo\left(M \right)}$ (cf. equation  \ref{top_str_cat_eqn}). We denote these limits by $\left( \Coo\left(M \right)_{\Dslash}, \Coo\left(\widetilde M \right)_{\Dslash}, G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M\right) \right)$ and \\$\left( \Coo\left(M \right), \Coo\left(\widetilde M \right), G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M\right) \right)$ respectively.  From the Definition \ref{inv_o*_lim_defn} it follows that there is an injective *-homomorphism  $\phi: \Coo\left(M \right)_{\Dslash} \to \Coo\left(\widetilde M \right)_{\Dslash}$. From 	$\widetilde	 \Dslash \bydef p^{-1}\Dslash$ (cf. \eqref{top_dlift_eqn})	it turns out that $\widetilde{\Dslash} = \phi\left( \Dslash\right)$. 

\end{empt}
\begin{theorem}\label{comm_inf_sp_tr_thm}
	The triple  $\left( \Coo_0\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , L^2\left(\widetilde M, \widetilde S \right)  , \widetilde{\Dslash}\right)$ is the \\$\left(C\left( M\right)  C_0\left( \widetilde{M}\right) , G\left(\left.\widetilde{M}~\right|M \right)\right)$-{lift} of $\left( \Coo_0\left( {M}\right) , L^2\left( M,  S \right)  , \widetilde{\Dslash}\right)$ \textit{induced by} $\rho_\Dslash$ (cf. Definition \ref{reg_triple_defn})
\end{theorem}

Follows from the construction \ref{top_reg_triple_empt} which is a specialization of the construction \ref{reg_triple_empt}.

	The Theorem \ref{comm_inf_sp_tr_thm} is a noncommutative analog of the Proposition \ref{comm_cov_mani_prop}.
