\chapter{Hausdorff blowing-up and coverings}\label{blowing_chap}
\paragraph*{}
If the spectrum of  $C^*$-algebra $A$ is Hausdorff then $A$ possess  a family of good properties. For example noncommutative coverings of $C^*$-algebras with Hausdorff spectra correspond to coverings of their spectra. Sometimes the spectrum of $C^*$-algebra can by replaced by its Hausdorff blowing-up and some results concerning $C^*$-algebras with  Hausdorff spectrum can be applied to $C^*$-algebras with Hausdorff blowing-up. We prove that noncommutative coverings of $C^*$-algebras correspond to coverings of Hausdorff blowing-up. The results of this chapter are used in both $C^*$-algebras with continuous trace (Hausdorff spectrum) and algebras of foliations   (non - Hausdorff spectrum). 
The "blowing-up" word is inspired by following reasons:
\begin{itemize}
	\item There is  the natural partially defined multi-valued surjective  map from the Hausdorff blowing-up to the spectrum (cf. \ref{blowing_empt}).
	\item  In the algebraic geometry   "blowing-up" means  excluding of singular points  (cf. \cite{hartshorne:ag}).
\end{itemize}

\section{Basic definitions}

\paragraph*{}
Before the  definition of blowing we consider an illustrative example.
For all $\th\in \R_+$ there  is the natural action of group  $G\bydef \Z\th/ \Z$ on the circle
$\sX\bydef S^1$. If $\th$ is rational then the space $\sX/G$ is Hausdorff otherwise it is not Hausdorff. How can we obtain $\sX/G$ algebraically? The Table \ref{hnh_alg_table} shows different methods of obtaining of the spectra.
\newline
\begin {table}[H]
\caption {Comparison of an invariant algebra and a crossed product} \label{hnh_alg_table}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
	\hline
	&$\sX/G$ is Hausdorff & $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff\\
	\hline
	&&\\
	$C\left( \sX\right)^G$ 	& $C\left( \sX/G\right)$	&$\C$\\
	& & \\
	%	&&\\
	Spectrum of $C\left( \sX\right)^G$ 	& $ \sX/G$	& A point\\
	& & \\
	\hline
	&&\\
	$C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ 	& $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\neq\C$	&$C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\neq\C$\\
	& & \\
	%&&\\
	Spectrum of $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ 	& $ \sX/G$	& $\sX/G$\\
	& & \\
	
	\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}
Thus the $C\left( \sX\right)^G$ invariant $C^*$-algebra does not always yield $\sX/G$ as a spectrum but the crossed product $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ does. 
Moreover since $C\left( \sX/G\right)$ can be trivial it does not know the map $\sX \to \sX/G$  but $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$ knows it, because there  is an inclusion.
$C\left(\sX \right) \subset C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G$. If $\sX/G$ is Hausdorff then sometimes a covering of $\sX/G$ can by find by following way:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find a covering $\widetilde\sX \to\sX$ with an action $G\times \widetilde\sX \to \widetilde\sX$,
\item Then there is the covering $\widetilde\sX / G \to \sX/G$.
\end{enumerate}
However if $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff this construction does not work. 
However there is an algebraic version of it given by:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Find a covering $\widetilde\sX \to\sX$ with an action $G\times \widetilde\sX \to \widetilde\sX$, and invective *-homomorphism $C\left( \sX\right)\hookto  C\left( \widetilde\sX\right)$,
\item Then there a noncommutative covering  $C\left( \sX\right)\rtimes G\hookto C\left( \widetilde\sX\right)\rtimes G $.
\end{enumerate}
The algebraic construction can be applied if $\sX/G$ is not Hausdorff.  The map $\sX \to \sX/G$ is yields a specialization of discussed below Hausdorff blowing up. 



%\paragraph*{}


\begin{definition}\label{blowing_defn}
Any  commutative $C^*$-subalgebra $C\cong C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$ is said to be  a \textit{Hausdorff blowing-up} of $A$  if for any irreducible representation $\rep_x: A \to B\left( \H\right)$ the space $\rep_x\left( C\right) \H$ is dense in $\H$. 
\end{definition}


\begin{empt}\label{blowing_empt}
If $\sX$ is the spectrum of $A$ then	for any $y\in \sY$ there is 
the set
$$
\sX_y \bydef \left\{\left. x\in\sX\right| \rep_x\left(C_0\left( \sY\right)\right)\neq \rep_x\left( I_y\right)   \right\}
$$
where $I_y = \left\{\left. a\in C_0\left( \sY\right) \right| a\left( y\right)= 0  \right\}$.
The map $y \mapsto \sX_y$ yields a partially defined multi-valued map from $\sY\to\sX$.
The map is surjective because for any $x \in \sX$ and for any maximal ideal $J_x \subset \rep_x\left(C_0\left( \sY\right)\right) $ there is a maximal ideal $I_y\subset C_0\left( \sY\right)$ such that $J_x= \rep_x\left(I_y\right)$.
\end{empt}
\begin{definition}\label{blowing_spectal_defn}
If the described in  \ref{blowing_empt} map is single-valued then we say that it is \textit{spectral}. It means that one has a subset $s\left( \sY\right)\subset \sY$ with the following equation 
\be\label{blowing_spectal_eqn}
\sY\supset s\left( \sY\right)\xrightarrow{s_\sY} \sX
\ee
where a map $s_\sY$ is surjective.
\end{definition}
!!! EXTENSION OF SPECTRAL REPRESENTATION
\begin{empt}
Let  $C\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $ be a blowing-up of $A$. If for any open subset $\sU \subset \sY$ we put
\be\label{blowig_su_eqn}
A_\sU \bydef C^*\text{-norm completion of } C_0\left(\sU \right) A  C_0\left(\sU \right)
\ee
then one has
\be\label{blowig_sue_eqn}
\begin{split}
\sU'\cap \sU'' =\emptyset\Rightarrow\left(  C_0\left(\sU' \right) A  C_0\left(\sU'' \right)\right)\left(  C_0\left(\sU'' \right)
A  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) = \{0\} \Rightarrow \\ A_{\sU'}A_{\sU''}= \{0\}.
\end{split}
\ee
\end{empt}

\begin{definition}\label{blowing_good_defn}
A Hausdorff blowing-up	$C\cong C_0\left( \sY\right) \subset M\left(A \right)$ is said to be \textit{good} if for any family of open sets $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sX\right\}$ such that $\sX = \cup \ \sU_\a$ a union $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A$.
\end{definition}
\begin{remark}\label{blowing_good_rem}
Let both $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sX\right\}$  and $\left\{\sU_\bt\subset \sX\right\}$ be families  of open sets such that  $\sX = \cup~\sU_\bt$ and for any $\bt$ there is $\a$ such that $\sU_\bt \subset \sU_\a$. If a union $\cup A_{\sU_\bt}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A$ then  $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ also generates  $A$. 
\end{remark}
\begin{empt}\label{blowing_strict_empt}
	Suppose that $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}$ is an approximate unit of $C_0\left( \sU\right)$ and let $a \in A_\sU$. For all $a \in A_\sU$  there is $a' \in A$ and $f \in C_0\left( \sU\right) $ such that $\left\|a - fa' \right\|\le \frac{\eps}{3}$. On the other hand there is $\la_0 \in \La$  such that $\left\|f - u_\la f \right\| < \frac{\eps}{3\left\|a' \right\|}$. It follows that
	$$
	\la\ge\la_0\Rightarrow\left\|a - u_\la a \right\|\le  \left\|a - fa'\right\|+ \left\|u_\la \left( a - fa'\right)  \right\|+\left\|a' - u_\la fa'\right\| < \eps.
	$$
	Similarly there is $\la'_0\in \La$ such that $\la\ge\la'_0\Rightarrow\left\|a - au_\la  \right\| < \eps$.
	In result one has the following limit
	\be\label{blowing_strict_eqn}
	\bt\text{-}\lim u_\la = 1_{M(A)}
	\ee
	with respect to the strict topology of $M\left( A\right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}).
\end{empt}

\begin{exercise}\label{blowing_exer}
Let $A$ be a  $C^*$-algebra, and let $C$ be the center of $M\left(A \right)$.
Proof that the inclusion $C\subset M\left( A\right)$  is a good {Hausdorff blowing-up}. 
\end{exercise}


\section{Blowing-up and noncommutative  coverings}
\paragraph*{}


Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a Hausdorff  blowing-up of $A$. If $\left(A, \widetilde{A}, G, \pi \right)$ is a noncommutative finite-fold covering then from the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} it follows that there is the natural inclusion $\varphi:M\left({A} \right) \hookto M\left(\widetilde{A} \right)$ of $C^*$-algebras. So there is the natural inclusion $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(\widetilde{A} \right)$. If $\sU\subset \sY$ is an open subset then there is an inclusion $C_0\left(\sU \right)A C_0\left(\sU \right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right)$. If  $\widetilde A_\sU$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right)$ then there is the natural injective *-homomorphism.

\be\label{blowing_jsu_eqn}.
j_{\sU}: A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU.
\ee
\begin{definition}\label{blowing_semi1_defn}
Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$- algebra. A Hausdorff  blowing-up $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$ of $A$ is said to be \textit{%(reducibly) 
	semilocally 1-connected} if for any $y\in \sY$ and every open neighborhood $\sV$ of $y$   there is an open neighborhood $\sU$ such that $\sU\subset \sV$ and  $A_\sU$ (cf. \eqref{blowig_su_eqn}) is %(reducibly) 
reducibly simply connected (cf. Definitions \ref{simply_connected_defn} \ref{simply_connected_red_defn}).
\end{definition}


\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_simply_conn_lem}

Let $A$ be a  connected $C^*$- algebra, and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$ be a 
{semilocally} 1-{connected} Hausdorff  blowing-up, with locally connected $\sY$. Then for each reduced noncommutative finite-fold covering $\left(A, \widetilde{A}, G, \pi \right)$, every $y\in\sY$,  each open neighborhood  there is an open connected neighborhood $\sU$ of $y$ such that $\sU\subset \sV$ and the given by \eqref{blowing_jsu_eqn} *-homomomorphism $j_{\sU}: A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ is an almost trivial disconnected noncommutative finite-fold covering (cf. Definition \ref{almost_trivial_defn}).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
From the Definition \ref{fin_defn} it turns out that there is an increasing net $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}\subset M\left( A\right)_+ $  of positive elements such that
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] There is the limit 
	\be\nonumber
	\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }
	\ee
	in the strict topology of $M\left(A \right)$ (cf. Definition \ref{strict_topology}).
	\item[(b)]  If for all   $\la\in\La$ both $A_\la$ and  $\widetilde A_\la$ are $C^*$-norm completions  of $u_\la A u_\la$ and  $u_\la\widetilde{A}u_\la$ respectively then for every $\la\in\La$ a quadruple
	$$
	\left(A_\la, \widetilde{A}_\la, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_\la} :A_\la\hookto \widetilde{A}_\la\right)	
	$$
	is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization. The action 	$G \times \widetilde{A}_\la\to \widetilde{A}_\la$, is the restriction on $\widetilde{A}_\la\subset \widetilde{   A}$ of the action $G\times  \widetilde{A}\to \widetilde{A}$.
\end{enumerate}
For any $\la\in \La$ there is an  ideal of $C_0\left(\sY \right)$ given by
$$
D_\la\bydef  \left\{\left. f \in C_0\left(\sY \right)\right| fu_\la = 0\right\}.
$$ 
Denote by
$$
C_\la\bydef \left\{\left. f \in C_0\left(\sY \right)\right| \forall f'\in D_\la \quad ff' = 0\right\}
$$
Both $D_\la$ and $C_\la$ are ideals of $\sY$ such that there are open subsets $\sV_\la$ and $\sU_\la$ of $\sY$ which satisfy to conditions $D_\la = C_0\left(\sV_\la\right)$ and $C_\la = C_0\left(\sU_\la\right)$. For all $\la\in \La$ an intersection $\sU_\la\cap \sV_\la$ is empty and a union $\sU_\la\cup \sV_\la$ is dense in $\sY$. From $\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }$ it follows that $\bigcap_{\La \in \la}\sV_\la = \emptyset$ and $\bigcup_{\La \in \la}\sU_\la = \sY$. For any $y\in\sY$ denote by  $\la_y\in  \La$ such that $y \in \sU_{\la_y}$. If both $A_y$ and $\widetilde A_y$ are $C^*$-norm completions of both $u_{\la_y}Au_{\la_y}$ and $u_{\la_y}\widetilde Au_{\la_y}$ respectively then 	$\left(A_y, \widetilde{A}_y, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_y}\right)$ is  a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization (cf. Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}).  It means that following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
	\item[(a)] 
	There are unitizations $A_y \hookto B$, $\widetilde{A}_y \hookto \widetilde{B}$.
	%	\item[(b)]$A = B\bigcap \widetilde{A}$,
	\item[(b)] There is a %(strong) 
	unital  noncommutative finite-fold quasi-covering	$\left(B ,\widetilde{B}, G, \widetilde{\pi} \right)$ such that
	$\pi = \widetilde{\pi}|_A$ (or, equivalently $A \cong \widetilde{A}\cap B$) and
	the action $G \times\widetilde{A} \to \widetilde{A}$ is induced by $G \times\widetilde{B} \to \widetilde{B}$.
\end{enumerate}
From the Definition \ref{fin_uni_defn} it follows that there is a finite set $\left\{\widetilde b_1, ..., \widetilde b_n\right\}\subset \widetilde B$, such that 
$$
\widetilde B = \widetilde b_1B +  ...+\widetilde b_nB
$$
If $\sU$ be an open neighborhood of $y$ such that $\sU\subset \sU_{\la_y}$ and $A_\sU$ is simply connected. From
\bean
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)A_y C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) B  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right),\\
\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)\widetilde A_y C_0\left(\sU \right)\right) \left( C_0\left(\sU \right) B  C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset C_0\left(\sU \right) \widetilde A_y  C_0\left(\sU \right).
\eean
and since $C_0\left(\sU \right) A C_0\left(\sU \right) $ and  $C_0\left(\sU \right) \widetilde A C_0\left(\sU \right) $ are dense in $A_\sU$ and $\widetilde A_\sU$.
it turns out that $\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and $\left( C_0\left(\sU \right)B C_0\left(\sU \right)\right)\subset M\left( A_\sU\right)$. If $\left\{v_\a \right\}$ is an approximate unit for of $C_0\left(\sU \right)$ then it is an approximate unit of both $M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and $M\left(\widetilde A_\sU\right)$ (cf. \eqref{blowing_strict_eqn}).  So all $b\in B$ and  $\widetilde b \in \widetilde B$ the both  nets  $\left\{v_\a bv_\a\right\}$ and   $\left\{v_\a \widetilde bv_\a\right\}$ are convergent with respect to strict topologies of $M\left( A_\sU\right)$ and of $M\left( \widetilde A_\sU\right)$. If both $B_\sU$ and $\widetilde B_\sU$ are $C^*$- algebras of strict limits of nets $\left\{v_\a bv_\a\right\}$ and   $\left\{v_\a \widetilde bv_\a\right\}$ then
$$
\widetilde B_\sU = \widetilde b^\sU_1 B_\sU + ... + \widetilde b^\sU_n B_\sU;\quad \widetilde b^\sU_j\bydef \bt\text{-}\lim v_\a \widetilde b_jv_\a; \quad j = 1,...,n.
$$
It follows that the natural inclusions $A_\sU \subset \widetilde B_\sU$ and $A_\sU \subset \widetilde B_\sU$ are unitizations, so
from the Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn} it follows that $\left(A_\sU,\widetilde A_\sU, G, \pi|_{A_\sU}\right)$ is  a reduced noncommutative finite-fold quasi-covering with unitization. From the Lemma \ref{quasi_red_lem} it turns out that $A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ a disconnected noncommutative finite-fold reduced  covering with unitization. On the other hand $A_\sU$ is reducibly  simply connected, so $A_\sU \hookto \widetilde A_\sU$ is   almost trivial disconnected noncommutative finite-fold covering of $A_\sU$.
\end{proof}

\begin{empt}\label{blowing_b_empt}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$- algebra and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn} and \ref{blowing_good_defn}) such that $\sY$ is connected and locally connected. Let $p: \widetilde \sY\to\sY$ be a transitive covering (cf. Definition \ref{top_transitive_defn}).
Let  $\left\{\sU_\a\subset\sU\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $p$ family, and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$  the $p$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$. (cf. Definition 
\ref{top_lconn_defn}).
Let $\mathfrak P$ be a set of $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}$-paths (cf. Definition \ref{top_gen_path_defn}).  Consider a subset  $\mathfrak G \subset \mathfrak P\times A$ such that $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)\in \mathfrak G$ if $\mathfrak p= \left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}, ..., \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n}\right)$ then there are $a_1\in A_{p\left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1 }\right) },...,a_n\in A_{p\left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n }\right) }$ such that $a = a_1\cdot...\cdot a_n$. There is an involution on $\mathfrak G$ given by $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)^*= \left( \mathfrak p^*,a^* \right)$ (cf. \eqref{top_path_inv_eqn}). The action $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)\times \widetilde \sY\to \widetilde \sY$ induces an action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)\times \mathfrak G\to \mathfrak G$.
If $\widetilde\B$ is a generated by $\mathfrak G$ free Abelian group, then both  involution and action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$ on $\mathfrak G$ induce involution and action of $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$ on $\widetilde\B$. There is multiplication on $\widetilde\B$ such that
\bean
\left( \mathfrak p_1,a_1 \right)\left( \mathfrak p_2,a_2 \right)
\bydef \\
\bydef\begin{cases}
	0 & \left( \mathfrak p_1,\mathfrak p_2 \right)\text{ is not composable (cf. Definition \ref{top_path_comp_defn})}\\
	\left( \mathfrak p_1\circ \mathfrak p_2,a_1a_2 \right) & \left( \mathfrak p_1,\mathfrak p_2 \right)\text{ is  composable}
\end{cases}
\eean
where  $\mathfrak p_1\circ \mathfrak p_2$ is given by \eqref{top_path_comp_eqn}, so  $\widetilde\B$ becomes a *-algebra. If $\A\subset A$ be the algebraically generated by $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ subalgebra then there is the left and right action of $\A$ on $\widetilde\B$. Let  $a \in A_{\sU_\a}$ and let $\widetilde b \in \widetilde \B$ be represented by the pair $\left(\mathfrak p, b\right)$ such that $\mathfrak p= \left(\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}, ..., \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_n}\right)$. If $p\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a_1}\right) \cap \sU_{\a} = \emptyset$, then we put $a\widetilde b = 0$. Otherwise there is the unique path $\mathfrak p' = \mathfrak p'' \circ \mathfrak p$ such that $\mathfrak p'' = \left(\widetilde \sU_{\widetilde\a}\right)$ and $p\left( \widetilde \sU_{\widetilde\a}\right) = \sU_\a$ (cf. Lemma \ref{top_path_lift_lem}). We put $a \widetilde b =\left(\mathfrak p', ab\right)$. The union $\cup A_{\sU_\a}$ algebraically generates $\A$ one has an action $\A \times \widetilde \B \to \widetilde \B$. Using *-operation one can obtain the right action of $\A$ on $\widetilde \B$ such that $\widetilde \B$ becomes an $\A$-bimodule.	There is a surjective *-homomorphism $p_{\widetilde\B}: \widetilde\B \to A$ given by $\left( \mathfrak p,a \right)\mapsto a$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY \right)$-invariant  *-seminorm $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde{\B}}$ on $\widetilde \B$ given by
\bean
\left\|\widetilde b \right\|_{\widetilde{\B}} = \sqrt{\left\|p|_{\widetilde{\B}}\left(\widetilde b\widetilde b^*\right)  \right\|}.
\eean 
The set
\be\label{blowing_ideal_eqn}
I_{\widetilde{\B}} = \left\{\left.\widetilde b \in \widetilde\B~\right| \left\| \widetilde b \right\|_\B=0\right\}
\ee
is an involutive two sided ideal. The seminorm on $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{	I_{\widetilde{\B}}}$ induces a norm $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde B/ I_{\widetilde{\B}}}$ on $\widetilde \A\bydef\widetilde \B/	I_{\widetilde{\B}}$, denote by $\widetilde \H_A$ the $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{\widetilde B/ I_\B}$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$.  The structure of $\A$-bimodule of $\widetilde{\B}$ induces the structure of the Hilbert $A$-bimodule on $\widetilde \H_A$. On the other hand the multiplication on	$\widetilde \A$ induces  an injective *-homomorhism
\be\label{blowing_end_eqn}
\widetilde \A\hookto \End_A\left( \widetilde \H_A\right) 
\ee
where $\End_A\left( \widetilde \H_A\right)$ means the $C^*$-algebra of adjoint endomorphisms. 
The $C^*$-norm on $\End_A\left(\widetilde \H_A\right)$ induces the $C^*$-norm on $\widetilde \A$. Let $\widetilde A$ be the $C^*$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$.
so $\widetilde A$ is a $C^*$-algebra. The algebra $\widetilde\B$ algebraically generated by elements $\left( \mathfrak p, a\right)$ where $\mathfrak p=\left(  \widetilde\sU_\a\right)$ and $a \in A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_\a\right) }$. If we denote  by $\mathfrak T$ a set of pairs $\left( \sU_\a, a\right)$, such that  $a \in A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_\a\right) }$ then there is the natural map $\mathfrak T\to \widetilde \B$. This map induces a map
\be\label{blowing_pt_eqn}
p_{\mathfrak T}:\mathfrak T\to \widetilde A
\ee
such that the image of $p_{\mathfrak T}$ generates $C^*$-algebra $\widetilde{A}$.
The action $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)\times \widetilde\sY\to \widetilde\sY$ naturally induces the action
\be\label{blowing_gpt_eqn}
G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)\times \mathfrak T\to \mathfrak T
\ee
\end{empt}

\ee

\subsection{Finite-fold coverings}
\paragraph{}
Here we prove that a finite-fold coverings of Hausdorff blowing-up yield noncommutative finite-fold coverings and vice versa.
\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_covi_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$-algebra, and let $C = C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. equation \eqref{blowing_a0x_eqn} and Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}).
Suppose that $\sY$ is a connected, locally connected space. For any transitive finite-fold covering $q: \widetilde \sY\to \sY$ there is 	 a  noncommutative finite-fold  reduced covering $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_defn}, \ref{fin_red_defn}) such that if $\varphi : M\left( A\right) \to M\left(A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)\right)$ is given by the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} then
$\left.\varphi\right|_{C_0\left( \sY\right) }= A_0\left(p \right)$. 

\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let  $\left\{\sU_\a\subset\sU\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $p$ family, and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$  the $p$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$. (cf. Definition 
\ref{top_lconn_defn}).	If $G$ is given by
$$
G \bydef \left\{ \left.g \in \Aut\left( A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) \right)~\right|~ ga = a;~~\forall a \in A\right\}
$$
then from the action \eqref{blowing_gact_eqn} it turns out that $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}~\right| \sY\right)= G$, it follows that the triple $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is  noncommutative finite-fold  pre-covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_pre_defn}). From the Lemma \ref{comm_direct_lem} it follows that there is an approximate unit   $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in \La}\subset C_c\left( \sY\right)_+$ for $C_0\left(\sY\right)$ such that $\supp u_\la$ is a connected set, for each $\la\in\La$.  Let both $A_\la$ and $A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)_\la$ be $C^*$-norm completions of $u_\la A u_\la$  and $u_\la A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) u_\la$ respectively, and us prove that  $\left\{u_\la\right\}$ satisfies to conditions (a), (b) of the Definition \ref{fin_defn}
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(a)] From \eqref{blowing_strict_eqn} one has  the limit 
	\bean
	\bt\text{-}\lim_{\la \in \La} u_\la = 1_{M\left(A \right) }
	\eean
	in the strict topology of $M\left(A \right)$.
\item[(b)] One needs proof that for every $\la\in\La$ a quadruple
$$
\left(A_\la, \widetilde{A}_\la, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_\la} :A_\la\hookto \widetilde{A}_\la\right)	
$$
is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization.
If for each $\la\in \La$ denote by $\sV_\la\bydef \supp u_\la$ and $\widetilde \sV_\la \bydef p^{-1}\left( \sV_\la\right)$, then there are natural inclusions $C\left( \sV_\la\right) \subset M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $C\left( \widetilde\sV_\la\right) \subset M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$. If $B$ and $\widetilde B$ are generated by $A_\la \cup C\left( \sV_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde A_\la \cup C\left(\widetilde \sV_\la\right)$ $C^*$-subalgebras of $M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$ then the given by the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} inclusion $\phi_\la: M\left(A_\la\right)\hookto M\left(\widetilde A_\la\right)$ is such that $\phi_\la\left(B \right)\subset \widetilde B$, i.e. there is the natural inclusion $\widetilde \pi: B \hookto\widetilde B$. Let us prove that $B$ and $\widetilde B$ satisfy to conditions (a) and (b) of the Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}.
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(a)]  From $B \subset M\left(A_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde B \subset M\left( \widetilde A_\la\right)$ it follows that both $A_\la \hookto B$  and $\widetilde{A}_\la \hookto \widetilde{B}$ are unitizations.
	\item[(b)] Since $p$ is a transitive covering the restriction $p|_{\widetilde \sV_\la}: \widetilde \sV_\la \to \sV_\la$ is also transitive covering. hence from  \ref{ctr_unity_empt} it follows that there is a finite sum
	\be\label{blowing_unity_sum_eqn}
	1_{C\left(\widetilde{\mathcal Y} \right) }= \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}^2_{\widetilde{\a}}\quad \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\in C\left(\widetilde \sY\right)
	\ee
	such that 		for any nontrivial $g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)$	one has
	\be\label{blowing_unity_orth_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}	\left(g \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} \right) = 0.
	\end{split}
	\ee
	If $\widetilde a \in \widetilde B$ then from \eqref{blowing_unity_sum_eqn} it follows that
	\be\label{ctr_unity_orthx_eqn}
	\widetilde a = \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right) 
	\ee
	From \eqref{blowing_unity_orth_eqn} it follows that if $g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)$ is not trivial then 
	\be\label{blowing_unity_orthxx_eqn}
	\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\left(g\left(  \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right) \right) = 		\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}	\left(g \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} \right) \left(g \widetilde{\a} \right) = 0\cdot \left(g \widetilde{\a} \right) = 0.
	\ee
	From the equations \ref{ctr_unity_orthx_eqn} and \ref{ctr_unity_orthx_eqn} it follows that
	$$
	\widetilde a = \sum_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A} }\widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}} a_\a\quad\text{where}\quad a_\a \bydef \sum_{g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right)}g\left( \widetilde{e}_{\widetilde{\a}}\widetilde a\right)\in B, 
	$$
	i.e. $\widetilde B$ is a finitely generated $B$-module. So $\left(B, \widetilde B,G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right),  \widetilde\pi\right)$ is an unital noncommutative finite fold covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_uni_defn}). From $ B \cap \widetilde A_\la=A_\la$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right) \times \widetilde A_\la= \widetilde A_\la$ it follows that\\ $\left( A_\la,\widetilde A_\la, G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY \right|\sY \right) , \widetilde\pi|_{A_\la}  \right)$ is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization.
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
Thus  $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is a  noncommutative finite-fold   covering, let us prove that it is reduced.\\
Let $\left\{\sU_\a\subset \sY\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ be a {compliant with} $p$ family and let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_{\a}\right\}_{\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}}$ is the $p$-{lift} of $\left\{\sU_\a\right\}_{\a \in \mathscr A}$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_lconn_defn}). From the equations \eqref{blowig_sue_eqn} and \ref{blowing_asu_eqn} it turns out then for all $\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}$ there is an  injective *-homomorphism 
\be\label{blowing_ds_eqn}
\left.A_0\left(p\right)\right|_{A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right) }}:A_{p\left( \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}\right)} \hookto \bigoplus_{g\in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right| \sY\right)}g\left.	\widetilde A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)\right._{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}
\ee
If  $\widetilde A' \subset A_0\left(\widetilde \sX \right)$ is a hereditary $C^*$-subalgebra  which contains $A_0\left( p\right)\left( A\right)$ then from the Definition \ref{hered_defn} it follows that $A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)_{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}\subset\widetilde A'$ for every 
 $\widetilde\a \in \widetilde{\mathscr A}$. On the other hand the $C^*$-algebra  $A_0\left(\widetilde \sX \right)$ is generated by the union $\bigcup A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY\right)_{ \widetilde\sU_{\widetilde\a}}$, so $\widetilde A' \subset A_0\left(\widetilde \sX \right)$.
 From the Definitions \ref{red_alg_defn} and \ref{fin_red_defn} it turns out that the  noncommutative finite-fold   covering $\left(A, A_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) , G\left(\left. \widetilde\sY\right| \sY\right) , A_0\left( p\right)  \right)$ is reduced.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_lift_d_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$- algebra and let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a good  blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn} and \ref{blowing_good_defn}) such that $\sY$ is connected and locally connected. Let $p_1: \widetilde \sY_1\to\sY$,  $p_2: \widetilde \sY_2\to\sY$ be a finite-fold transitive coverings (cf. Definition \ref{top_transitive_defn}) such that there is a transitive covering $p^2_1:  \widetilde \sY_2\to  \widetilde \sY_1$ with $p_2 = p_1\circ p^2_1$.

\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(i)]		There are  natural actions $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_1~\right| \sY\right) \times A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)\to A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ and $G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_2~\right| \sY\right) \times A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2\right)\to A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2 \right)$.
	\item[(ii)] One has
	\be\label{blowing_g_inv_eqn}
	\begin{split}
		G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_2~\right| \sY \right) 
		A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)   =			G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sY}_1~\right| \sY \right) 
		A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)
	\end{split}
	\ee
	where the natural inclusion $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)\subset A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2 \right)$ is implied.
	
\end{enumerate} 

\end{lemma}
\begin{proof} 
(i)	 Follows from the equation \eqref{blowing_gact_eqn}.\\
(ii) From the Corollary \ref{com_norm_cor} one has an exact sequence of group homomorphisms
$$
\left\{e\right\} \to 	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right) \to 	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right) \to 	G\left(\widetilde\sY_1~|~\sY \right) \to \left\{e\right\},
$$
so $G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_1~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$  is a normal subgroup of $	G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right)$.
Direct check shows that 	
\be\label{blowing_ga_eqn}
A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)\cong \left\{\left.\widetilde a \in A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)\right|g\widetilde a= \widetilde{a}\quad \forall g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right) \right\}
\ee
If   $g \in  G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\sY \right)$ and $ g'\in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ then there is $ g''\in G\left(\left.\widetilde\sY_2~\right|~\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$ such that $g'g= gg''$. It turns out that
$$
\forall \widetilde a\in\widetilde A_1\quad g'\left(g\widetilde a \right) = g\left(g''\widetilde a \right)= g\widetilde a,  
$$
i.e. $g\widetilde a$ satisfies to \eqref{blowing_ga_eqn}, therefore $g\widetilde a\in A_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1 \right)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{empt} 
Let $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ be a reduced finite-fold noncommutative covering (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_defn}, \ref{fin_red_defn})  let $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left(A \right)$  be a blowing-up of $A$.  Let $\sX$ and $\widetilde\sX$ be spectra of $A$ and $\widetilde A$ respectively, and let $q: \widetilde\sX\to\sX$ be a given by the Lemma \ref{cov_spectrum_lem} continuous map.
Since $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ is reduced one has $\rep_{ \widetilde{x}}\left(\widetilde A \right) \cong \rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left(\widetilde A \right) = \rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left( A \right)$.
Put 
\be\label{blowing_wc_eqn}
\widetilde C \bydef \left\{\left.\widetilde c \in M\left( \widetilde A\right) \right| \forall \widetilde x \in \widetilde \sX \quad \rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left( \widetilde c \right)\in \rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left( C\right) \right\}.
\ee
A $C^*$-algebra	$C$ is a commutative, so for all $\widetilde x\in \widetilde\sX$ both $\rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left( C\right) $ and $\rep_{  \widetilde{x }}\left(\widetilde C\right)$ are commutative, it turns out that $\widetilde C$ is a commutative  $C^*$-algebra.  The algebra	$\rep_{q\left(  \widetilde{x}\right) }\left( C\right)$ is $G$-invariant for all $\widetilde x \in \widetilde\sX$, so the action  $G\times  M\left( \widetilde A\right)\to  M\left( \widetilde A\right)$ is such that $G \widetilde C=\widetilde C$, so one can define the natural action $G \times  \widetilde C\to \widetilde C$. There is an injective *- homomorphism $C \hookto \widetilde C$.  If $\widetilde\sY$ is the spectrum of $\widetilde C$ then $\widetilde C \cong C_0\left(\widetilde\sY\right)$ and the  homomorphism $C \hookto \widetilde C$ induces a surjective continuous map $p:\widetilde\sY\to \sY$. From the natural action   $G \times  \widetilde C= \widetilde C$ one can define an action  $G \times  \widetilde \sY\to \widetilde \sY$. There is the natural inclusion  
\be\label{blowing_inc_eqn}
C_0\left(\widetilde\sY\right)\hookto M\left(\widetilde A \right) 
\ee
\end{empt}


\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_uni_lem}
	Consider the above situation. If $\sY$ is compact then
then the map $p$ is a transitive finite-fold covering.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
From the Definition \ref{fin_uni_defn} it follows that $\widetilde A$ is a finitely generated left and right $A$-module.
If $C\left(\widetilde\sY\right)$ is not  a finitely generated $C\left(\sY\right)$-module then from the Theorem \ref{fin_gen_thm} it follows that there is an infinite set $\left\{M_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}$ of $C\left(\sY \right)$-submodules of $C\left(\widetilde{\sY}\right)$ such that 
$$
C\left(\widetilde{\sY}\right)=\sum_{\la \in \La} M_\la,
$$
but there is no  a finite subset $\La_0\subset \La$  such that 
$$
C\left(\widetilde{\sY}\right) = \sum_{\la \in \La_0} M_\la.
$$
For any $\la\in \La$ the space  $M_\la \widetilde{A}$ is a right $A$-submodule of $\widetilde{A}$.
From $C\left(\sY \right) A = A$ and $C\left(\widetilde\sY \right) \widetilde  A = \widetilde A$ one has 
$$
\widetilde{A}=\sum_{\la \in \La}M_\la \widetilde{A} 
$$
but there is no  a finite subset $\La_0\subset \La$  such that 
$$
\widetilde{A}=\sum_{\la \in \La_0}M_\la \widetilde{A}.
$$
From the Theorem \ref{fin_gen_thm} it follows $\widetilde{A}$ is not a finitely generated $A$-module, it contradicts with the definition \ref{fin_uni_defn}. So $C\left(\widetilde\sY\right)$ is   a finitely generated $C\left(\sY\right)$, and from the Theorem \ref{pavlov_troisky_thm} it follows that $p$ is a finite-fold covering. The action $G \times \widetilde A\to \widetilde A$ induces the action $G \times \widetilde \sY\to \sY$ which yields a surjective homomorphsm $G \to  G\left( \left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY\right)$. If $G' \bydef \ker \left(G \to  G\left( \left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY\right)\right)$ then $G/G'$ nontivially acts on $\widetilde\sY$ and $\sY \cong \widetilde\sY/\left(G/G'\right)$. So the covering $p$ is transitive.
\end{proof}


\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_cov_lem}
Let $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ be a  noncommutative finite-fold   covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_defn}), and let $C = C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $  be a good  Hausdorff blowing-up of $A$ (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}). If $\widetilde C = C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right)\hookto M\left( \widetilde A\right) $ is the given by \eqref{blowing_inc_eqn} then following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(i)] There is the natural transitive finite-fold covering $q: \widetilde \sY\to \sY$.
	\item[(ii)] If  $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ is a reduced  noncommutative finite-fold   covering (cf. Definition  \ref{fin_red_defn}) and the Hausdorff blowing-up $C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $   is semilocally 1-connected (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_semi1_defn})	then one has 
	\bean
	\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)\cong \left(A,\widetilde A\left(\widetilde\sY \right) , G\left( \left. \widetilde \sY\right|\sY\right) , A_0\left(q\right)  \right).
	\eean
\end{enumerate}	
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}(i) 
Consider an increasing net $\left\{u_\la\right\}_{\la\in\La}\subset M\left( A\right)_+ $ 	required by the Definition \ref{fin_defn}.
For any $\la\in\La$ both 
\bean
C_\la  \bydef \left\{\left. a \in C\right| a\left\{\left. b \in M\left( A\right) \right| u_\la b u_\la = 0 \right\}=\{0\}  \right\},\\
\widetilde C_\la \bydef  \left\{\left.\widetilde a \in \widetilde C \right| \widetilde a\left\{\left.\widetilde b \in M\left(\widetilde A \right)\right| u_\la\widetilde b u_\la = 0 \right\}=\{0\}  \right\}.
\eean 
are  ideals of both $C$ and 
$\widetilde C$ respectively.
From the Proposition \ref{hered_spectrum_prop} it follows that there are open subsets $\sU_\la\subset \sY$ and $\widetilde \sU_\la\subset \widetilde\sY$ such that $C_\la \cong C_0\left(\sU_\la\right)$ and  $\widetilde C_\la \cong C_0\left(\widetilde \sU_\la \right)$. If  $A_\la$ and  $\widetilde A_\la$ are $C^*$-norm completions  of $u_\la A u_\la$ and  $u_\la\widetilde{A}u_\la$ then from the condition (b) of the definition  \ref{fin_defn} it turns out that 		$$
\left(A_\la, \widetilde{A}_\la, G, \left.\pi\right|_{A_\la} :A_\la\hookto \widetilde{A}_\la\right)	
$$
is a noncommutative finite-fold covering with unitization (cf. Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}). Let  $\left(B_\la ,\widetilde{B}_\la, G, \widetilde{\pi}_\la \right)$ be an untital  pre-covering which is required by the condition (b) of the Definition \ref{fin_comp_defn}.
If
\bean
D_\la \bydef \left\{\left.  a \in  B_\la\right| \forall  b\in    C_\la \quad   a   b=   b  a\in  C_\la  \right\},\\
\widetilde D_\la \bydef \left\{\left. \widetilde a \in \widetilde B_\la\right| \forall \widetilde b\in   \widetilde C_\la \quad  \widetilde a  \widetilde b=  \widetilde b \widetilde a\in \widetilde C_\la  \right\},\\
\eean
then $ D_\la\subset M\left(  C_\la\right)$ and $\widetilde D_\la\subset M\left( \widetilde C_\la\right)$. So both   $C_\la$ and $\widetilde C_\la$ are essential ideals of $D_\la$ and $\widetilde D_\la$ respectively. Since both $D_\la$ and $\widetilde D_\la$ commutative and unital (because $1_{B_\la}\in D_\la$ and  $1_{\widetilde B_\la}\in \widetilde D_\la$) there are compact sets $\sY_\la$ and $\widetilde\sY_\la$ such that $ D_\la= C\left(  \sY_\la\right)$ and  $\widetilde D_\la= C\left( \widetilde \sY_\la\right)$. Moreover both $\sU_\la$ and $\widetilde\sU_\la$ are dense subsets of $\sY_\la$ and $\widetilde\sY_\la$ respectively (cf. Example \ref{comm_ess_exm}).
From the Lemma \ref{blowing_uni_lem}
it follows that the inclusion $ D_\la\hookto \widetilde D_\la$ yields a  is a transitive finite-fold covering $q: \widetilde \sY_\la\to \sY_\la$ such that $G\cong G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY_\la\right| \sY_\la \right)$.
The restriction $\left.q_\la\right|_{\widetilde \sU_\la}: \widetilde \sU_\la\to \widetilde \sU_\la$ is also a covering.
It turns out that  $q_{\widetilde\sU_\la}\bydef  \left.q_{\widetilde\sY_\la}\right|_{\widetilde\sU_\la}\widetilde\sU_\la\to \sU_\la$ is a covering. From $\nu \le \mu $ it follows that $u_\nu \le u_\mu$ and  $\sU_\nu \subset \sU_\mu$. The family of coverings $\left\{q_{\widetilde\sU_\la}: \widetilde\sU_\la\to \sU_\la\right\}_{\la\in \La}$ yields a finite-fold covering
$$
q: \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \widetilde\sU_\la\to \bigcup_{\la\in \La} \sU_\la.
$$
Indeed the above covering is a finite-fold covering 
$$
q: \widetilde\sU \to \sU
$$
The given by the Lemma \ref{ind_mult_inv_lem} action $G \times M\left(\widetilde A\right)\to M\left(\widetilde A\right)$ is such that $GC_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right) = C_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)$, so there is the natural action $G\times  \widetilde\sY\to \widetilde\sY$. If
$$
G' \bydef \left\{g \in G\left| g \widetilde f = \widetilde f \quad \forall \widetilde f \in C_0\left( \widetilde\sY\right)  \right.\right\}
$$
then $G'$ is a normal subgroup of $G$. If $ G'' \bydef G/G'$ then there is a nontrivial action $G'' \times \widetilde \sY \to \widetilde \sY$ such that $\sY = \widetilde\sY/G''$. If follows that the covering $q$ is transitive.\\
(ii) For any $y\in \sY$ select an evenly covered by $q$ (cf. Definition \ref{comm_cov_pr_defn}) connected neighborhood $\sV_y$. For every $y\in\sY$ select a neighborhood $\sU_y\subset\sV_y$ such that (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_semi1_defn}) $A_\sU$ (cf. \eqref{blowig_su_eqn}) is %(reducibly) 
reducibly simply connected (cf. Definitions \ref{simply_connected_defn} \ref{simply_connected_red_defn}). One has $\bigcup_{y \in \sY}= \sY$.
For each $y\in \sY$ we select a connected open set $\widetilde \sU_y$ which is homeomorphically mapped onto  $\sU_y$. For any $y \in \sY$ the given by \eqref{blowing_jsu_eqn} *-homomomorphism $j_{\sU_y}: A_{\sU_y} \hookto \widetilde A_{\sU_y}$ is an almost trivial disconnected noncommutative finite-fold covering (cf. Lemma \ref{blowing_simply_conn_lem} and Definition \ref{almost_trivial_defn}). It means that $\widetilde A_{\sU_y}$ is direct sum of isomorphic to $A_{\sU_y}$ algebras
\be\label{blowing_n_eqn}
\widetilde A_{\sU_y} \cong \bigoplus_{j=1}^nA_{\sU_y}
\ee
On the other hand 
\be\label{blowing_g_eqn}
\widetilde A_{\sU_y}= \bigoplus_{g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right) }g \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}
\ee
where $\widetilde \sU_y\subset\widetilde\sY$ is an open connected homeomorphically mapped onto  $\sU_y$ set. Comparison of \eqref{blowing_n_eqn} and \eqref{blowing_q_eqn} yields the following
\be\label{blowing_ay_eqn}
\begin{split}
\forall g \in G\quad \forall y\in \sY \quad g \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}\cong A_{\sU_y},\\
n = \left| G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)\right|. 
\end{split}
\ee
It follows that there is an inclusion $G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)\subset G$. Otherwise  from $G/G'\cong G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)$ it follows that there is a surjecive homomorphism $G\to G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)$. In result one has $G$ is a Cartesian product $G \cong G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)\times G'$. For all $g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)$ and $g'\in G'$, one has
$$
g'g\widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}=g\widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}
$$
i.e. there is an action $G'\times g\widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}\to g\widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}$. From \eqref{blowing_ay_eqn}  it turns out there is the natural action $G'\times A_{\sU_y}\to g\widetilde A_{\sU_y}$, so if the action $G' \times \widetilde A \to \widetilde A$ then its restriction $G\times A\to A$ is not trivial as well. It contradicts with the Definition \ref{fin_pre_defn}, so $G'$ is trivial and $G\cong G\left(\left.\widetilde \sY\right|\sY \right)$. 
%where the above isomorphism is the  $p$-$\widetilde{\sU}$-{lift} $u$(cf. Definition \ref{blowing_lift_desc_defn}).
Let  $\widetilde A'$ be a $C^*$-subalgebra of $\widetilde A$ generated by a union $\bigcup_{\left(g,y\right)\in G \times \sY} g \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}$. If $\widetilde a \in \widetilde A_+$ is positive then $a = \sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde a \in A_+$ is a positive element. The union $\bigcup_{y\in\sY} A_{\sU_y}$ generates $A$ so from the Lemma  \eqref{essential_lem} it follows that  is $y \in \sY$ and $b\in A_{\sU_y}$ such that $ab \neq 0$.
If $\widetilde b\bydef  \lift^p_{\widetilde{\sU}_y}\left( b\right) $ is the  $p$-$\widetilde{\sU}_y$-{lift} (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_lift_desc_defn}) then
$$
b = \sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde b
$$

It follows that
\bean
ab = \left( \sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde a\right)\left( \sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde b\right) =\sum_{\left( g_1,g_2\right) \in G\times G} \left(g_1 \widetilde a\right) \left(  g_2 \widetilde b \right) \neq 0.
\eean
so there is a pair $\left( g_1,g_2\right) \in G\times G$ such that $\left(g_1 \widetilde a\right) \left(  g_2 \widetilde b \right) \neq 0$. Since $G$ acts by *-automorphisms one has
\be\label{blowing_cov_good}
g_1^{-1}\left( \left(g_1 \widetilde a\right) \left(  g_2 \widetilde b \right)\right) = \widetilde a  \left(g_1^{-1}  g_2 \widetilde b \right)\neq 0.
\ee
From $g_1^{-1}  g_2 \widetilde b \in g_1^{-1}  g_2 \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}$ it follows that  $\widetilde A'$ is an essential ideal of  $\widetilde A$. Direct check shows that $G\widetilde A'= \widetilde A'$. If $\widetilde a \in \widetilde A_+\setminus \widetilde A'$ then $\sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde a \in A$ and $\sum_{	g \in G} g \widetilde a \notin \widetilde A$, i.e. there is a contradiction. So one has $\widetilde A'=\widetilde A$ i.e. the $C^*$-algebra $A$ is generated by the union $\bigcup_{\left(g,y\right)\in G \times \sY} g \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}$.
If $\widetilde \B$ is an explained in \ref{blowing_b_empt} *-algebra then there is homomorphism of Abelian groups
\bean
\varphi_{\widetilde \B}:\widetilde \B \to \widetilde A,\\
\left(\mathfrak p = \left(g_1\widetilde \sU_{y_1},..., g_n\widetilde \sU_{y_n}\right),a= a_1\cdot ...\cdot a_n \right) \mapsto \lift^p_{g_1\widetilde{\sU}_{y_1}}\left(a_1 \right) \cdot ...\cdot  \lift^p_{g_n\widetilde{\sU}_{y_n}}\left(a_n \right) 
\eean
where $\lift^p_{\widetilde{\sU}}$ means the $p$-$\widetilde{\sU}$-{lift} (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_lift_desc_defn}). Direct check shows that $\varphi_{\widetilde \B}$ is *-homomorphism and $\ker \varphi_{\widetilde \B} =I_{\widetilde \B} $ where is the given by \eqref{blowing_ideal_eqn} two sided ideal. So there is an inclusion $\varphi_{\widetilde \B/I_{\widetilde \B}}:{\widetilde \B} /I_{\widetilde \B} \hookto \widetilde A$ which is dense because the image of $\varphi_{\widetilde \B/I_{\widetilde \B}}$ contains the union  $\bigcup_{\left(g,y\right)\in G \times \sY} g \widetilde A_{\widetilde \sU_y}$. Since the $C^*$-norm on $\widetilde A$ is equivalent to the $C^*$-norm of $\widetilde \A\bydef \varphi_{\widetilde \B/I_{\widetilde \B}}\left(  \widetilde \B/I_{\widetilde \B}\right) $ induced by the inclusion \eqref{blowing_end_eqn}  the completion $C^*$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$ in $\widetilde A$ is naturally isomorphic to $\overline A$. On the other hand  $A_0\left(\widetilde \sY \right)$ is the $C^*$-norm completion of $\widetilde \A$  (cf. Definition \ref{blowing_lift_a_defn}), so one has $\widetilde \A\cong A_0\left(\widetilde \sY \right)$. Using the direct check one can prove that $\pi = A_0\left(p\right)$.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_good_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left(\sY \right) \to M\left( A\right)$ be a good,  semilocally 1-connected,  Hausdorff blowing-up (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn},\ref{blowing_spectal_defn} \ref{blowing_good_defn}, \ref{blowing_semi1_defn}). For any reduced noncommutative finite-fold covering $\left(A, \widetilde A, G, \pi\right)$ the explained in \ref{blowing_inc_eqn} Hausdorff blowing-up $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right) \to M\left(  \widetilde A\right)$ is good and   semilocally 1-connected.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
\ref{blowing_good_rem}
Denote by $p:  \widetilde \sY\to \sY$ the given by the Lemma \ref{blowing_cov_lem} finite-fold transitive covering. Let $\left\{\widetilde\sU_\a \subset \widetilde \sY \right\}_{\a\in \mathscr A}$ be a family of open subsets, such that $\widetilde \sY = \cup \widetilde \sU_\a$. For any $y\in \sY$ select a connected evenly covered by $p$ neighborhood $\sV_y$. If $\left\{\widetilde y_1, ..., \widetilde y_n\right\}\bydef p^{-1}\left(y \right)$ then for all $j= 1,...,n$ we select $\a_j \in  \mathscr A$ such that $\widetilde y_j \in \widetilde\sU_{\a_j}$. Let $\sU_y$ be a connected open neighborhood of $y$ such that $\sU_y \subset \sV_y \bigcap \left(\bigcap_{j=1}^n p\left( \widetilde\sU_{\a_j}\right) \right)$
The  family of open sets $\left\{\widetilde\sU_y  \right\}_{y\in \sY}$ satisfies to conditions of \ref{top_lconn_part}. If $\left\{\widetilde\sU_\bt \subset \widetilde \sY \right\}_{\a\in \mathscr B}$ is the $p$-\textit{lift} of $\left\{\sU_y\right\}$ (cf. Definition \ref{top_lconn_defn}) then from the proof of the Lemma \ref{blowing_cov_lem} it follows that a union $\cup~\widetilde\sU_\bt$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)$. On the other hand each $\bt\in \mathscr B$  there is $\a\in \mathscr A$ such that $\widetilde\sU_\bt \subset \widetilde\sU_\a$, so a union $\cup~\widetilde\sU_\a$ generates $C^*$-algebra $A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right)$ (cf. Remark \ref{blowing_good_rem}), so the  Hausdorff blowing-up $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right) \to M\left(  \widetilde A\right)$ is good.
From \eqref{blowing_ay_eqn} it follows that $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right) \to M\left(  \widetilde A\right)$ is semilocally 1-connected.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{blowing_comp_cor}
Let $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ be a  noncommutative finite-fold   covering (cf. Definition \ref{fin_defn}), and let $C = C_0\left( \sY\right)\hookto M\left( A\right) $  be a good, semilocally 1-connected,  Hausdorff blowing-up of $A$.  (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}, \ref{blowing_semi1_defn}). If both $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ and  $\left(\widetilde A,\widetilde{\widetilde A}, \widetilde G, \widetilde \pi \right)$ are reduced  noncommutative finite-fold   coverings (cf. Definitions \ref{fin_defn}, \ref{fin_red_defn}) then there is a reduced  noncommutative finite-fold   covering  $\left( A,\widetilde{\widetilde A}, \widetilde{\widetilde G}, \widetilde{\widetilde \pi} \right)$ such that $\widetilde{\widetilde \pi} = \widetilde{\pi}\circ \pi$ and there is the following exact sequence
\be\label{blowing_ex_eqn}
\{e\}\hookto \widetilde G \hookto \widetilde{\widetilde G} \to G \to\{e\}.
\ee
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
From the Lemma \ref{blowing_cov_lem} it follows that there is a transitive finite-fold covering $q: \widetilde \sY \to \sY$ such that  $\left(A,\widetilde A, G, \pi \right)$ is equivalent to $ \left(A,\widetilde A\left(\widetilde\sY \right) , G\left( \left. \widetilde \sY\right|\sY\right) , A_0\left(q\right)  \right)$. From the Lemma \ref{blowing_good_lem} it turns out that  the explained in \ref{blowing_inc_eqn} Hausdorff blowing-up $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right) \to M\left(  \widetilde A\right)$ is good and   semilocally 1-connected. From the \ref{blowing_cov_lem} it turns out that there is a transitive finite-fold covering $\widetilde q: \widetilde{\widetilde \sY}  \to \widetilde \sY$ such that $\left(\widetilde A,\widetilde{\widetilde A}, \widetilde G, \widetilde \pi \right)$ is e quivalent to $ \left(\widetilde A,\widetilde A\left(\widetilde{\widetilde \sY} \right) , G\left( \left. \widetilde{\widetilde \sY}\right|\widetilde\sY\right) , A_0\left(\widetilde\sY \right) \left(\widetilde q\right)  \right)$. From
\bean
\pi =  A_0\left( q \right),\\
\widetilde \pi = A\left( \widetilde\sY\right)_0\left(\widetilde q\right)
\eean 
and \eqref{blowing_aq_eqn} it follows that $\widetilde{\widetilde \pi} = \widetilde{\pi}\circ \pi$. The sequence \eqref{blowing_ex_eqn} is equivalent to the following exact sequence
$$
\{e\}\hookto G\left( \left. \widetilde{\widetilde \sY}\right|\widetilde\sY\right) \hookto G\left( \left. \widetilde{\widetilde \sY}\right|\sY\right) \to G\left( \left. \widetilde \sY\right|\sY\right) \to\{e\}
$$
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}\label{blowing_spectal_lem}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left(\sY \right) \to M\left( A\right)$ be a good, spectral, semilocally 1-connected,  Hausdorff blowing-up (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn},\ref{blowing_spectal_defn} \ref{blowing_good_defn}, \ref{blowing_semi1_defn}). For any reduced noncommutative finite-fold covering $\left(A, \widetilde A, G, \pi\right)$ the explained in \ref{blowing_inc_eqn} Hausdorff blowing-up $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right) \to M\left(  \widetilde A\right)$ is   spectral.

\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let both $\sX$ ans $\widetilde \sX$ be spectra of both $A$ and $\widetilde A$ respectively, and $p: \widetilde \sX \to \sX$ be a given by the Lemma \ref{cov_spectrum_lem}. If $\widetilde x_1, \widetilde x_2\in \widetilde\sX$ are such that $p\left(\widetilde x_1 \right) \neq p\left(\widetilde x_2 \right)$ and $\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1}$, $~\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}$ are maximal proper ideals of $C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right)$ such that
\be\label{blowing_ideals_eqn}
\begin{split}
	\rep_{\widetilde x_1}\left(C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right)  \right) \neq \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1},\\
	\rep_{\widetilde x_2}\left(C_0\left( \widetilde \sY\right)  \right) \neq \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}
\end{split}
\ee
then  ideals $I_{q\left(\widetilde y_1 \right) }= \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1}\cap C_0\left( \sY\right)$  and $I_{q\left(\widetilde y_2 \right) }= \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}\cap C_0\left( \sY\right)$ are different since the Hausdorff blowing up $C_0\left(\sY \right) \to M\left( A\right)$ is spectral. So $\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1}\neq \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}$ If $p\left(\widetilde x_1 \right) =p\left(\widetilde x_2 \right)$ and $\widetilde x_1\neq \widetilde x_2$ then there is a nontrivial $g \in G$ such that $\widetilde x_2 = g \widetilde x_1$. If $\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1}$, $~\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}$ are satisfying to \eqref{blowing_ideals_eqn} ideals the $q\left( \widetilde y_1\right) \neq q\left( \widetilde y_2\right)$ or $q\left( \widetilde y_1\right) = q\left( \widetilde y_2\right)$. If $q\left( \widetilde y_1\right) \neq q\left( \widetilde y_2\right)$ then $\widetilde I_{\widetilde y_1}\neq \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}$. If $q\left( \widetilde y_1\right) = q\left( \widetilde y_2\right)$ then $ \widetilde y_2= g \widetilde y_1$, so since $G$ freely acts on $ \widetilde \sY$ one has $I_{\widetilde y_1}\neq \widetilde I_{\widetilde y_2}$.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof} 
		From the Lemma \ref{blowing_covi_lem} one has two  reduced noncommutative finite-fold coverings 	$\left(A,  	\widetilde A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_1\right),{G\left( \left.\widetilde{\sY}_1~\right|\sY\right)}, A_0\left( p_1\right)  \right)$ and $\left(A,  	\widetilde A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_2\right),{G\left( \left.\widetilde{\sY}_2~\right|\sY\right)}, A_0\left( p_2\right)  \right)$. From the Lemma \ref{ind_qusai_lem}  there is an  approximate unit of $A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_2\right)$ contained in $A$. The $A_0\left(p_1 \right)$ image of this  approximate unit  is the same approximate unit of  $A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_2\right)$. From  the Proposition \ref{mult_str_pos_prop} it turns out that there is the natural inclusion $\varphi: M\left(A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_1\right)\right)\to M\left(  A_0\left(  \widetilde\sY_2\right)\right)$. Let both If  both $\widetilde \sU_1\subset\widetilde\sY_1$ and $\widetilde\sU_2\subset\widetilde\sY_2$ are open connected sets homemorphically mapped onto $\sU = p_1\left(\widetilde \sU_1\right)= p_1\left(\widetilde \sU_1\right)$.	
 From the equation \eqref{blowing_hereditary_g1_eqn} one can deduce that for all $\widetilde f_1 \in C_0\left( \widetilde \sY_1\right)$ such that $\supp \widetilde \sU_1$ one has
$$
\varphi\left( \widetilde f_1\right) = \sum_{\stackrel{g_2 \in G_2}{\phi\left(g_2 \right)=g_1 }}\lift_{g_2\widetilde\sU_2}\left( \desc_{p_1}\left( \widetilde f_1\right) \right) \in C_0\left( \widetilde\sY_2\right).
$$
The described above elements $\widetilde f_1$ generate $C^*$-algebra $C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1\right)$ so $\varphi\left( C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1\right)\right) \subset  C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2\right)$. An injective *-homomorphism $\varphi|_{C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1\right)}: C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_1\right)\hookto C_0\left(\widetilde\sY_2\right)$ induces a surjective continuous map $q^2_1:\widetilde\sY_2\to \widetilde\sY_1$ such that there is a commutative diagram

\begin{theorem}\label{blowing_functor_thm}
Let $A$ be a $C^*$-algebra, and let $C_0\left(\sY \right) \to M\left( A\right)$ be a good  semilocally 1-connected Hausdorff blowing-up (cf. Definitions \ref{blowing_defn}, \ref{blowing_good_defn}, \ref{blowing_semi1_defn}).	Suppose that  $\sY$ is a connected, locally connected  space.
Denote by $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$A$ a category of reduced noncommutative  finite-fold  coverings of $A$,  i. e.
\begin{itemize}
	\item  Objects of $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$A$ are noncommutative  finite-fold  coverings of $A$.
	\item If $\pi': A\hookto \widetilde A'$ and  $\pi'':A \hookto \widetilde A''$ are objects of $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$A$ then the morphism from $\pi'$ to $\pi''$ is an injective *-homomorphism $\pi: \widetilde A' \hookto  \widetilde A''$ such that the following diagram commutative.
	\newline
	\begin{tikzpicture}
		\matrix (m) [matrix of math nodes,row sep=3em,column sep=4em,minimum width=2em]
		{
		\widetilde A'  & & \widetilde A' \\ 
			& \widetilde A  & \\};
		\path[-stealth]
		(m-1-3) edge node [above] {$\pi$} (m-1-1)
		(m-2-2) edge node [left]  {$\pi'~~$} (m-1-1)
		(m-2-2) edge node [right] {$~~\pi''$} (m-1-3);
	\end{tikzpicture}
	\\ 	
\end{itemize}
Following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(i)] 	If the category $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$\sY$ is given by the Definition \ref{top_fin_cov_defn} then contravariant functor $A_0:\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$\sX \to \mathfrak{FinCov}$-$A$ yields equivalence (cf. Equation \ref{category_equivalence_definition}) between the  
		category $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$A$ and the category $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$\sY^{\mathrm{op}}$ which is dual to $\mathfrak{FinCov}$-$\sY$ (cf. Definition \ref{dual_cat_defn}).
	\item[(ii)] Any unordered pair of *-homomorphisms $\left( \pi',\pi''\right) $ from the above diagram is {compliant} (cf. Definition \ref{compliant_covering_defn}).
\end{enumerate}

\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
(i) Follows from the Lemmas \ref{blowing_covi_lem},  \ref{blowing_cov_lem}, \ref{blowing_pcomt_lem} and the Corollary \ref{blowing_comp_cor}.\\
(ii) One needs check conditions (a)-(d) of the Definition \ref{compliant_covering_defn}
\begin{enumerate}
	\item [(a)] Follows from the Lemmas \ref{blowing_pcomt_lem} and \ref{blowing_covi_lem}.
	\item[(b)] Follows from the equation \eqref{blowing_g_inv_eqn}.
	\item[(c)]  Follows from the surjective homomorphism $ G\left(\left.\widetilde \sX_2~\right|\sX \right)\to 	G\left(\left.\widetilde \sX_1~\right|\sX \right)$. 
	\item[(d)] Follows from the Exercise \ref{blowing_pcomt_exer}.
\end{enumerate}



\end{proof}

\begin{proof}
!!!!	Note that 

(i)
If $\widetilde{b} \in C_0\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(\mathcal{X}, \left\{A_x\right\}, \sF \right)\right] \right)$ and $\eps > 0$ then from the Definition \ref{c_c_def_2} it turns out there is a compact set $\widetilde{\mathcal V}\subset \widetilde{\mathcal X}$ such that $\left\| \widetilde{b} \left(\widetilde{x}  \right) \right\| < \frac{\eps}{2\left\|\widetilde{a}\right\|}$ for any $\widetilde{x} \in \widetilde{\mathcal X} \setminus \widetilde{\mathcal V}$. Let us prove that the set
$$
G_0=\left\{\left. g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)\right| \widetilde \sV \cap g \widetilde\sU \neq \emptyset \right\}
$$
If $G_0$ is not finite then there is an infinite closed set $\widetilde\sX' = \left\{\widetilde x_g \right\}_{g \in G_0}$ such that $\widetilde x_g \in \widetilde \sV \cap \widetilde \sU$. If $g'\neq g''$ then both $g' \widetilde\sU$ and $g'' \widetilde\sU$ are open neighborhoods of both $\widetilde x_{g'}$ and $\widetilde x_{g''}$ such that $g' \widetilde\sU\cap g'' \widetilde\sU = \emptyset$. It means that the set $\widetilde\sX'$ is discrete. From $\widetilde\sX' \subset \widetilde\sV$ it follows that $\widetilde\sX'$ is compact, however any infinite discrete set is not compact. From this contradiction we conclude that the set  $G_0$ is finite. For any $G' \subset  G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ such that $G_0\subset G'$ a following condition holds
$$
\left\|\widetilde{b}\left(\sum_{g \in G' } g\widetilde{a}-\sum_{g \in G_0 } g\widetilde{a} \right)  \right\| +
\left\|\left(\sum_{g \in G' } g\widetilde{a}-\sum_{g \in G_0 } g\widetilde{a} \right)\widetilde{b}  \right\| < \eps.
$$
The	above equation means that the series is convergent in the strict topology of $M\left(C_0\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(\mathcal{X}, \left\{A_x\right\}, \sF \right)\right] \widetilde{\mathcal X}\right) \right)$.\\
(ii)  If $\widetilde{b} \in C_0\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(\mathcal{X}, \left\{A_x\right\}, \sF \right)\right] \widetilde{\mathcal X}\right)$ and $\widetilde{x}_0 \in \widetilde{\mathcal X}$ then $\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0} = {a}_{p\left(  \widetilde{x}_0\right) } \widetilde{b}_{\widetilde{x}_0}$.  If ${a}_{ p\left(  \widetilde{x}_0\right) }  = 0$ then $\left( \widetilde{a}\widetilde{b}\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0} = 0$. Otherwise there is $\widetilde{x}'_0\in \widetilde{\mathcal U}$ such that $p\left(\widetilde{x}'_0 \right)= p\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right)$. From \eqref{comm_lift_eqn} it turns out $\widetilde{a}_{\widetilde{x}'_0} = a_{ p\left(\widetilde{x}'_0 \right)}$. The covering $p$ is transitive, so there is the unique $g \in  G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right)$ such that  $\widetilde{x}_0 = g\widetilde{x}'_0$. So one has  $\left( g \widetilde{a}\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0}= a_{p\left(\widetilde{x}_0 \right)} $. If $g' \neq g$ then $g\widetilde{\mathcal U} \bigcap \widetilde{\mathcal U} = \emptyset$. It turns out that $\left( g' \widetilde{a}\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0}= 0$ for any $g'\neq g$. Hence one has
$$
\left(\sum_{g' \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } g'\widetilde{a} \right)_{\widetilde{x}_0} = 	\left(g\widetilde{a} \right)_{\widetilde{x}_0}= c^{-1}_{\widetilde y_0} \left( {a}_{ p\left(  \widetilde{x}_0\right)} \right) \text{ where } c_{\widetilde y_0}\text{ is given by }\eqref{blowing_ct_iso_eqn},
$$  
it follows that
$$
\left( \left(\sum_{g' \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } g'\widetilde{a} \right)\widetilde{b}\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0}= 	\left(\widetilde{b} \left(\sum_{g' \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } g'\widetilde{a} \right)\right)_{\widetilde{x}_0} = \widetilde{b}_{\widetilde{x}_0}  {a}_{ p\left(  \widetilde{x}_0\right)}.
$$
The above equation means that $$
\sum_{g \in G\left(\left.\widetilde{\sX}~\right|\sX\right) } g\widetilde{a} = a =\lift_p \circ \desc_p\left( \widetilde{a}\right)\in M\left(C_0\left( \lift_p\left[C\left(\mathcal{X}, \left\{A_x\right\}, \sF \right)\right]\right)  \right)
.$$	\\
%(iii) and (iv) Follow from Definition \ref{blowing_lift_desc_defn} the homeomorphism $\widetilde{\sU} \cong \sU$.
\end{proof}
