\part{Applications to the Theoretical Physics}\label{phys_part}

\chapter{String field theory and Hausdorff non-Hausdorff duality}\label{haus_non_haus_dul_sec}
\paragraph*{}

The most impressive directions of present day theoretical physics are superstring theory and noncommutative geometry. Both directions  are aimed to describe fundamental physical laws, i.e. these directions have the single purpose. However these directions seem very different. The superstring theory operates with the classical geometry of Hausdorff spaces. Noncommutative geometry replaces spaces with $C^*$-algebras, which simultaneously describe both "outer space" (stars and galaxies) and "inner space" (fundamental particles and forces). The spectra of $C^*$-algebras should or  should not be Hausdorff. In \cite{connes_lott:particle} the Standard model is described by an operator algebra which generates a $C^*$-algebra with Hausdorff spectrum (cf. Section \ref{oa_sec}). In \cite{connes_rieffel:nc_ym} a physical model is described by a $C^*$-algebra with non-Hausdorff spectrum.
\paragraph*{}
Before the so-called "duality revolution" there were believed to be five distinct versions of string theory, plus the (unstable) bosonic and gluonic theories. String duality is a class of symmetries in physics that link different string theories.
\paragraph*{}
Here examples   of a duality between Hausdorff and non-Hausdorff geometry are presented. It is proven that the Hausdorff and non-Hausdorff geometry can be  manifestations of the single physical theory.

\section{Basic ingredients}
\paragraph{}
Here  well known physical results are described. The combination of these results yields an example of   Hausdorff non-Hausdorff duality.
\section{Examples of Hausdorff non-Hausdorff duality}\label{exm_sec}

\paragraph*{}
Here we apply the theory of quantized coverings for the construction of examples of Hausdorff non-Hausdorff duality.
\paragraph*{}
The torus $\T^2$ can be regarded as a quotient $\T^2 = \R^2/\Z^2$. There is the natural infinite covering $\widetilde p : \R^2\to\T^2$. From the Lemma \ref{top_uni_exist_spa_lem} it follows that $\widetilde p$ is the universal covering such that $G\left(\left.\R^2\right|\T^2\right)\cong \Z^2$. Let us select base points $x_0\in \T^2$ and $\widetilde x_0 \in \R^2$ such that $\widetilde p: \left(\R^2, \widetilde x_0\right)\to \left(\T^2 x_0\right)$ is a pointed map. Consider the family of all pointed finite-fold coverings $\left\{p_\la:\left(\sX_\la, x^\la_0\right)\to \left(\T^2 ,x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in \La}$ such that for any $\la\in \La$ there is a pointed covering $\widetilde p_\la: \left(\R^2, \widetilde x_0\right)\to \left(\sX_\la, x^\la_0\right)$ which satisfies to the following condition $\widetilde p_\la\circ p_\la=\widetilde p$. The group $\Z^2$ is residually finite  (cf. Definition \ref{residually_finite_defn}), hence from the Lemma \ref{top_res_fin_lem} it fo $\R^2$ is the topological inverse noncommutative limit (cf. Definition \ref{top_topological_inv_lim_defn}) of the category 
$
\mathfrak{S}_{\left(\T^2, x_0\right)}\left\{p_\la: \left( \sX_\la, x^\la_0\right) \to \left( \T^2, x_0\right)\right\}_{\la\in\La}.
$
Let $\widetilde \sF$ be a foliation on $\R^2$ which  corresponds to  a vector field $\tilde{X}$ on $\R^2$ given by
\[
dx = \th dy
\]
where $\th  \in \R\setminus\Q$ is an irrational number. Since $\widetilde \sF$ is invariant with respect to the action $\Z^2 \times\R^2 \to \R^2$ there is the foliation $\sF_\th$ on $\T^2$ such that $\widetilde \sF$ is the $\widetilde p$ -lift of $\sF_\th$ (cf. Definition \ref{fol_cov_defn}). The Lemma \ref{foli_poi_alg_lem} yields both  a {pointed finite foliation category} (cf. Definition \ref{foli_cat_defn}) and a pointed algebraical  finite covering category $\mathfrak{S}_{C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF\right)}$ (cf. Definition (ref. \ref{comp_pt_defn}) 
From the Theorem \ref{foli_main_thm} it follows that the triple $\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right), C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right), \Z^2 \right)$ is  the  { infinite noncommutative covering} of $\mathfrak{S}_{C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th, x_0\right)}$, (cf. Definition \ref{main_defn}). The transversal
$$
\widetilde N = \left\{\left.\left(0, y \right)\in \R^2\right| y \in \R \right\}\subset \R^2
$$
is complete and $N \bydef \widetilde p\left(\widetilde N \right)$ is also a complete transversal. There are $C^*$-algebras $C^*_r\left( \G^{N}_{N}\right)$ and  $C^*_r\left( \G^{\widetilde N}_{\widetilde N}\right)$ given by \ref{foli_pseudo_empt}.
From the Lemma \ref{foli_stab_lem} it turns out that
\be\label{foli_stab_eqn}
\begin{split}
C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)\cong C^*_r\left( \G^{N}_{N}\right)\otimes\K,\\
C^*_r\left(\R^2,  \widetilde\sF\right) \cong C^*_r\left( \G^{\widetilde N}_{\widetilde N}\right)\otimes\K.
\end{split}
\ee
Similarly to \ref{foli_n_cat_empt}  there is a good   pointed algebraical  finite covering category
\bean
\begin{split}
	\mathfrak{S}_{C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)}	\bydef\\
	\bydef\left\{\left\{\pi_\la : C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)\hookto C^*_r\left(\G^{N_\la}_{N_\la}\right)\right\}, 	\left\{\pi^\mu_\nu :C^*_r\left(\G^{N_\mu}_{N_\mu}\right)\hookto C^*_r\left(\G^{N_\nu}_{N_\nu}\right) \right\}\right\}.
\end{split}
\eean
From the Theorem  \ref{foli_n_cat_thm} it follows that $\left(C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right), C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right), \Z^2 \right)$ is  the  { infinite noncommutative covering} of the good   pointed algebraical  finite covering category $\mathfrak{S}^{\mathrm{pt}}_{C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)}$
It is proven in \cite{connes:ncg94} that
\be
C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)\cong C\left( \T^2_\th\right) 
\ee
where $C\left( \T^2_\th\right)$ is a noncommutative torus (cf. Definition \ref{nt_defn}).
Let us provide physical interpretations of the above results.
\begin{exm}\label{exm_sec_1_exm}
Consider   the  { infinite noncommutative covering}  $$\left(C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right), C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right), \Z^2 \right).$$ The foliation $C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right)$ is a fibration (cf. Definition \ref{foli_fibration_defn}) so from the Proposition \ref{foli_tens_comp_prop} it follows that there is the isomorphism
$C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$. Clearly $C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ is a $C^*$-algebra with continuous trace, so its spectrum is the Hausdorff space $\R$. From the Theorem \ref{foli_irred_hol_thm} it follows that the spectrum of $C^*_r\left(\T^2, \sF_\th\right)$ equals to the non-Hausdorff space $\R/\left(\Z+ \Z\th\right)$. The factors $C^*$-algebra $C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ have the following physical interpretation:
\begin{itemize}
	\item The factor $C_0\left(\R\right)$ corresponds to the outer physical space $\R$.
	\item The infinitely dimensional algebra $\K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ corresponds   to the inner space, i.e. it matches to the string field.
\end{itemize}
Similarly to the expressed on the Table \ref{geo_alg_table} situation the covering transformation group $\Z^2$ simultaneously acts on both $C_0\left(\R\right)$ and $\K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$, i.e. it is a twisted action. Let us describe this action. Any $a \in \R$ yields a homeomorphism $x \mapsto x + a$ of $\R$ so it gives a *-automorphism $U_a$ of $C_0\left( \R\right)$.  On the other hand there is *-automorphism $V$ of $\K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ induced by a homeomorphism $x \mapsto x + 1$ of $\R$. The action of $\Z^2\times C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right)\to C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF\right)$ of the covering transformation group $\Z^2$ corresponds to the action $\Z^2\times\left( C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)\right) \to C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ given by
\be\label{foli_nontriv_buble_eqn}
\left(n_1, n_2\right)\cdot \left(a_1\otimes a_2 \right) = U_{n_1 + n_2\th} a_1 \otimes V^{n_2}a_2
\ee
for all $\left(n_1, n_2\right)\in \Z^2$ and  $a_1\otimes a_2 \in C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$.
As well as the equation \eqref{nontriv_buble_eqn} the equation \eqref{foli_nontriv_buble_eqn} can be regarded as twisted covering transformation. Both  equations \eqref{nontriv_buble_eqn} and \eqref{foli_nontriv_buble_eqn}  yield nontrivial vector bundles from trivial ones. 
\end{exm}
	
	\begin{exm}\label{exm_sec_2_exm}
		Consider   the  { infinite noncommutative covering}  $$\left(C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right), C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right), \Z^2 \right).$$ 
From the equations \eqref{foli_stab_eqn} it follows that the spectrum of $C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{\widetilde N}\right)$ is homeomorphic to the Hausdorff spectrum of 	$C^*_r\left(\R^2,  \widetilde\sF\right)$ and the spectrum of $C^*_r\left(\G^{N}_{N}\right)\cong C\left(\T_\th\right)$ is homeomorphic to the non-Hausdorff spectrum of 	$C^*_r\left(\T^2,  \sF\right)$.	Let us consider a groupoid $\G$ (cf. Definition \ref{groupoid_defn}) which coincides with $\Z\times\Z$ as a set and satisfies to the following relations
\bean
s\left(\left( n_1, n_2\right)\right)   = \left(n_1, n_1\right),\\ 
r\left(\left( n_1, n_2\right)\right)  = \left(n_2, n_2\right),\\
\left( n_1, n_2\right)\circ \left( n_2, n_3\right)= \left( n_2, n_3\right),\\
\left( n_1, n_2\right)^{-1}= \left( n_2, n_1\right)
\eean
for all $n_1,n_2,n_3 \in \Z$. If $C^*_r\left( \G\right)$ is a reduced $C^*$-algebra of $\G$ (cf. Definition \ref{foli_groupoid_red_defn}) then one can prove that
$$
 C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)\cong C_0\left(\R \right)\otimes C^*_r\left( \G\right).
$$ 
Similarly to the Example \ref{exm_sec_1_exm} the factors $C^*$-algebra $  C_0\left(\R \right)\otimes C^*_r\left( \G\right)$ have the following physical interpretation:
		\begin{itemize}
			\item The factor $C_0\left(\R\right)$ corresponds to the outer physical space $\R$.
			\item The infinitely dimensional algebra $C^*_r\left( \G\right)\cong\K\left(\ell^2\left(\Z \right)  \right) $ corresponds   to the inner space, i.e. it matches to the string field.
		\end{itemize}
	A given by $\left(n_1, n_2 \right) \mapsto \left( n_1 + 1, n_2 + 1\right)$ automorphism of $\G$ yields the *-automorphism $V$ of $C^*_r\left( \G\right)$.
 The action of $\Z^2\times C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)\to C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)$ of the covering transformation group $\Z^2$ corresponds to the action $\Z^2\times\left( C_0\left(\R \right)\otimes C^*_r\left( \G\right)\right) \to C_0\left(\R \right)\otimes C^*_r\left( \G\right)$ given by
		\be\label{foli_nontriv_buble2_eqn}
		\left(n_1, n_2\right)\cdot \left(a_1\otimes a_2 \right) = U_{n_1 + n_2\th} a_1 \otimes V^{n_2}a_2
		\ee
		for all $\left(n_1, n_2\right)\in \Z^2$ and  $a_1\otimes a_2 \in C_0\left(\R \right)\otimes C^*_r\left( \G\right)$.
	\end{exm}
	\section{Resume}
\paragraph*{}
Here we explain why both $C^*$-algebras  $C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF \right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( \ell^2\left(\Z\right)\right)$) and $C^*_r\left(\T^2, \mathcal{F}_\th \right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)\otimes\K$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{ N}_{  N}\right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)$) can be regarded as manifestation of the single physics. Our arguments have two parts:
\begin{itemize}
\item Analysis of the KaluzaKlein theory.
\item Comparison of the Examples \ref{exm_sec_1_exm} and \ref{exm_sec_2_exm} with the KaluzaKlein theory.
\end{itemize} 
\subsection{Analysis of the KaluzaKlein theory}
%\subsubsection{KaluzaKlein theory}
\paragraph*{}
Similarly to the section 
The KaluzaKlein theory assumes that physical space is equivalent (homeomorphic) to the Cartesian product
\be
M \times K \cong M \times \widetilde K / G\left( \mathcal{\widetilde{K}}~|~K\right).
\ee
One can assume that physical laws on $M \times K$ and $M \times \widetilde K$ are equivalent but the space of physical states on $M \times K$ is the $G\left( {\widetilde{K}}~|~K\right)$ invariant subspace of the space of physical states on $M \times \widetilde K$.
Similarly the physical laws on  $C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF \right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( \ell^2\left(\Z\right)\right)$) and $C^*_r\left(\T^2, \mathcal{F}_\th \right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)\otimes\K$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{ N}_{  N}\right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)$) are equivalent. However the  space of physical states on $C^*_r\left(\T^2, \mathcal{F}_\th \right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)\otimes\K$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{ N}_{  N}\right)\cong C\left(\T^2_\th\right)$) is the $\Z^2$- invariant subspace of the space of physical states on $C^*_r\left(\R^2, \widetilde \sF \right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( L^2\left(\R\right)\right)$ (resp. $C^*_r\left(\G^{\widetilde N}_{ \widetilde N}\right)\cong C_0\left(\R\right)\otimes \K\left( \ell^2\left(\Z\right)\right)$).

\chapter{Wilson Lines and Noncommutative Covering Spaces}
\paragraph{} Commutative geometry has a lot of local structures, for example local sections of bundles. There are  bundles such that they have no global sections. Let $p: P \to M$ is a bundle such that $p$ has no global sections. Let $\pi : \widetilde{M} \to M$ be the universal covering projection, and $\widetilde{p}: \widetilde{M} \to M$ be the pullback \cite{spanier:at} of $p$ by $\pi$. Then $\widetilde{p}$ can have global sections. Any locally pure gauge field can be locally represented by \eqref{pure_gauge}, but cannot be represented by \eqref{pure_gauge} globally in general case. However pullback of this field can be globally repesented  by \eqref{pure_gauge}. Noncommutative geometry has no local sections. However there is the noncommutative generalisation of covering projections \cite{ivankov:cov_pr_nc_torus_fin,ivankov:infinite_cov_pr}. Local pure gauge fields can be regarded as global pure gauge fields on universal noncommutative covering projections. Locally gauge fields satisfy \eqref{pure_gauge} which can be rewritten in physical notation \cite{alekseev_bytsko:wilson_nc_tori}
\begin{equation} \label{Ag}
	\partial_i g = i A_i * g \,.
\end{equation}
This equation has a noncommutative analog.  Let $A^{\infty}$ be a smooth algebra and $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$ be a finitely generated projective smooth $A^{\infty}$ module.
Let $(A^{\infty}, \widetilde{A^{\infty}}, G, _{A^{\infty}}M_{\widetilde{A^{\infty}}})$ be a noncommutative covering projection (See Appendix \ref{appendix_nc_cov}). Spaces $A^{\infty}$,  $\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$, $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$ are operator spaces. Let denote $\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}=\mathcal{E}^{\infty} \otimes _{A^{\infty}}\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$ where $\otimes$ means the Haagerup tensor product. The $\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}$ module can be regarded as pullback of $\mathcal{E}^{\infty}$. Any vector $X \in \mathrm{Lie}G$ can be lifted to the vector $\widetilde{X}\in \mathrm{Lie}\widetilde{G}$ where $\mathrm{Lie}\widetilde{G}$ is a Lie algebra of infinitesimal transformations of the $\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$. Any connection $\nabla : \mathcal{E}^{\infty} \to \mathcal{E}^{\infty} \otimes \Omega^1A^{\infty}$ can be lifted to $G$ equivariant connection $\widetilde{\nabla}: \widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}} \to \widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}} \otimes \Omega^1\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$. Otherwise any connection $\widetilde{\nabla}: \widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}} \to \widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}} \otimes \Omega^1\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$ naturally induces a map $\widetilde{\nabla}':\mathrm{End}_{\widetilde{A^{\infty}}}\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}\right) \to \mathrm{End}_{\widetilde{A^{\infty}}}\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}\right) \otimes \Omega^1\widetilde{A^{\infty}}$.
Noncummutative analog of \eqref{Ag} is given by
\begin{equation}\label{nc_Ag}
	\widetilde{X}U = \widetilde{\nabla}_{\widetilde{X}}U; \ \forall X \in \mathrm{Lie}G, \ U\in \mathrm{Aut} \left(\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}\right).
\end{equation}
$U$ is a noncommutative analog of a global gauge transformation on the universal covering space.
Wilson line can be regarded as a group homomorphisms $G \to \mathrm{Aut}\left(\widetilde{\mathcal{E}^{\infty}}\right)$ given by
\begin{equation}\label{wilson_rel}
	g \mapsto (gU) \cdot U^{-1}
\end{equation}
where $g \in G(\widetilde{A^{\infty}}|A^{\infty})$ and $U$ satisfies \eqref{nc_Ag}.

\section{Alternative Description of  Wilson Lines}
\paragraph{} As well as in \ref{alter_prot} (See \cite{green_schwarz_witten:superstring}) we can define an alternative approach to Wilson lines. Suppose that there is a spectral triple $(\mathcal{A}, H, D)$ \cite{varilly:noncom}. In \cite{ivankov:cov_pr_nc_torus_fin,ivankov:infinite_cov_pr} I defined noncomutative covering projection $(\widetilde{A}, \widetilde{H}, \widetilde{D})$ with a group of covering transformations $G(\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}|\mathcal{A})$, such that there is the natural *-homomorphism $\mathcal{A} \to M(\widetilde{\mathcal{A}})$ and representation $\pi: \mathcal{A} \to U(\widetilde{H})$.
Suppose that $\rho: G(\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}|\mathcal{A}) \to U(\widetilde{H})$ is a representation such that
\begin{equation*}
	\widetilde{D} \rho(g)h = \rho(g) \widetilde{D}h, \ \forall h \in \mathrm{Dom}(\widetilde{D}).
\end{equation*}
Let $\widetilde{H}_0 = \{h \in \widetilde{H} \ | \ \pi(g)h = \rho(g)h\}$. Algebra $A$ naturally acts on $\widetilde{H}_0$ and we have a twisted spectral triple $(\mathcal{A}, \widetilde{H}_0, \widetilde{D})$ which can be regarded as description of Wilson line.

	\end{equation}
	\begin{equation}\label{vp_v}

\subsection{Hausdorff spaces}
\paragraph*{}
Here I follow to \cite{munkres:topology}.
Topologies in which one-point sets are not closed, or in which sequences can  converge to more than one point, are considered by many mathematicians to be somewhat strange. They are not really very interesting, for they seldom occur in other branches
of mathematics. And the theorems that one can prove about topological spaces are rather limited if such examples are allowed. Therefore, one often imposes an additional condition that will rule out examples like this one, bringing the class of spaces
under consideration closer to those to which one's geometric intuition applies. The condition was suggested by the mathematician Felix Hausdorff, so mathematicians have come to call it by his name. The notion of Hausdorff space is given by the  Definition \ref{haudorff_defn}

\begin{example}
	A real line $\R$ is a Hausdorff space. The group of integers $\Z$ acts on $\R$ by shifts. The quotient space $\R/\Z$ is equivalent to the circle $S^1$ which is also a Hausdorff space. 
\end{example}
\begin{example}\label{non_h_exm}
	If $\th \in \R\setminus\Q$ is an irrational number then te quotient space $\R/\left(\Z+ \Z\th\right)$ is not Hausdorff.
\end{example}
\begin{remark}
	Below we consider the duality between physical models on the Hausdorff space $\R$ and the non-Hausdorff space $\R/\left(\Z+ \Z\th\right)$.
\end{remark}



\subsection{KaluzaKlein theory}\label{kk_sec}
\paragraph*{}
The KaluzaKlein theory assumes that physical space is equivalent (homeomorphic) to the Cartesian product
\be
M \times K
\ee
of the manifolds, where the manifold $K$ is compact and $M$ is not compact. The compact manifold $K$ may be represented as a quotient $K \bydef \widetilde K / G\left( {\widetilde{K}}~|~K\right)$ where there is a covering  $\widetilde{K}\to K$ and $G\left( {\widetilde{K}}~|~K\right)$ is a covering group. The manifold $\widetilde{K}$ should not be compact.
\chapter{Commutative Wilson Lines}\label{comm_prot}
\begin{empt}{\it Standard description of Wilson lines} \cite{green_schwarz_witten:superstring}. Here the physical notation is used.
	Let $M$ be a compact Riemann manifold, and let $A$ be a locally pure gauge field, i.e. $A$ can be locally represented by following way
	\begin{equation}\label{pure_gauge}
		A_i = \partial_i U \cdot U^{-1}
	\end{equation}
	where $U$ is the gauge transformation. Whether \eqref{pure_gauge} is also true globally is another story. Condition \eqref{pure_gauge} is equivalent to that the field stength equals to zero \cite{green_schwarz_witten:superstring}.
	If the manifold is not simply connected, $\pi_1(M) \neq \{e\}$ then there is a more general possibility that appears in electrodynamics as the Bohm-Aharonov effect. Let $\gamma$ be a noncontractible loop in $M$, beginning and ending at the same point $x$. Then "Wilson line"
	\begin{equation}\label{gauge_transformation}
		U_{\gamma} = P \ \mathrm{exp} \oint\limits_{\gamma} A \cdot dx
	\end{equation}
	is gauge invariant, and if $U_{\gamma}\neq 1$ it cannot be set to one by gauge transformation, $U_{\gamma}$ depends only on $[\gamma] \in \pi_1(M)$. If $G$ is the gauge transformation group then is a group homomorphism
	\begin{equation}\label{from_fund_to_gauge}
		\varphi: \pi_1(M)\to G,
	\end{equation}
	\begin{equation*}
		[\gamma] \mapsto U_{\gamma}.
	\end{equation*}
\end{empt}
\begin{empt}\label{alter_prot} {\it Alternative description of Wilson lines}.
	In this construction I follow to \cite{green_schwarz_witten:superstring} 16.4.1. Let $\widetilde{M}$ be a simply connected manifold, and let $F$ be a discrete symmetry group which acts freely. Let $M = \widetilde{M}/F$. An ordinary field $\psi(x)$ is equivalent to a field on $\widetilde{M}$ that obeys
	\begin{equation}\label{invariant_simple}
		\psi(fx)=\psi(x); \ \forall f \in F.
	\end{equation}
	Then we can generalize \eqref{invariant_simple} as follows. There is a natural isomorphism $\pi_1(M) \approx F$, and from \eqref{from_fund_to_gauge} it follows that there is a natural homomorphism
	\begin{equation}\label{from_trans_to_field}
		F\to G,
	\end{equation}
	\begin{equation*}
		f \mapsto U_f.
	\end{equation*}
	Now we require that $\psi$ obey not \eqref{invariant_simple} but
	\begin{equation}\label{invariant_twist}
		\psi(fx)=U_f\psi(x); \ \forall f \in F.
	\end{equation}
	This operation enables us replace guage field \eqref{gauge_transformation} by "twist" in boundary conditions \eqref{invariant_twist}. The gauge field $A$ which obeys \eqref{gauge_transformation} (resp. field $\psi$) is replaced with the trivial gauge field (resp. field $\psi'$ which obey \eqref{gauge_transformation}). Field $\psi'$ is given by
	\begin{equation*}
		\psi'(y) = \left(P \ \mathrm{exp} \int\limits_{\omega} A' \cdot dx\right) \psi(\pi(y))
	\end{equation*}
	where
	\begin{itemize}
		\item $\pi: \widetilde{M} \to M$ is a covering projection.
		\item $\omega : [0,1] \to \widetilde{M}$ is such that $\omega(0) = y_0$ is a fixed point, $\omega(1)=y$.
		\item $A'$ is a lift of $A$ by $\pi$.
	\end{itemize}
	This construction is similar to passive/active approach to physical transformations. Change of a gauge field is similar to a passive transformation of a coordinat system, a change of field is similar to an active transformation of point's position. Both transformations describe the same physical phenomenon.
\end{empt}

\begin{empt}{\it Replacement of closed paths by covering projections}.
	Construction from \cite{green_schwarz_witten:superstring} can be generalized such that the universal covering is replaced by a covering  $\pi:\widetilde{M} \to M$ such that the image of the composition
	\begin{equation*}
		\pi_1(\widetilde{M})\xrightarrow{\pi_1(\pi)} \pi_1(M) \xrightarrow{\varphi} G
	\end{equation*}
	coincides with image of $\varphi$. In this case homomorphism \eqref{from_fund_to_gauge} can be replaced with
	\begin{equation}\label{from_trans_to_gauge}
		G(\widetilde{M}|M) \to G
	\end{equation}
	where $G(\widetilde{M}|M)$ is a group of covering transformations \cite{spanier:at}.
\end{empt}
